headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: So good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. Today's earnings call will last 45 minutes and will include 30 minutes for your questions.Before we begin, I want to mention that our speakers will be referring to slides, which can be viewed by going to
componenttext:
So good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. Today's earnings call will last 45 minutes and will include 30 minutes for your questions.
Before we begin, I want to mention that our speakers will be referring to slides, which can be viewed by going to nordstrom.com in the Investor Relations section. Today's discussion may include forward-looking statements, so please refer to the slide showing our safe harbor language.
Participating in today's call are Blake Nordstrom, Co-President; and Mike Koppel, Chief Financial Officer, who will discuss the company's fourth quarter and 2015 performance and the outlook for fiscal 2016. Joining them in the Q&A session will be Pete Nordstrom; and Erik Nordstrom, co-President; and Jamie Nordstrom, President of Stores.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Blake.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon, everyone. We're encouraged that even through this current retail environment, we continue to gain market share. We added roughly $1 billion to our top line, delivering total sales growth of 8%. For the fourth quarter, we had
componenttext:
Thank you, and good afternoon, everyone. We're encouraged that even through this current retail environment, we continue to gain market share. We added roughly $1 billion to our top line, delivering total sales growth of 8%. For the fourth quarter, we had a 1% comp increase as we anticipated, which was consistent with our third quarter's increase of 0.9%.
As we look ahead to 2016, we have always considered 2015 to be a peak investment year. That hasn't changed. What has changed is the current environment that we are facing, which requires us to pivot even more as we remain focused on improving profitability. In response, we are making adjustments to reduce expense and capital spending in 2016 and in the coming years.
For 2015, total sales in our full-price business, inclusive of Canada and Trunk Club, increased 5%. And off-price, inclusive of Rack stores and NordstromRack.com and HauteLook, sales increased 14%. 
From a merchandising perspective, we're always pursuing newness in fashion to increase our relevance with customers. For example, we've continued our success with brands like Topshop, Madewell, Brandy Melville and Charlotte Tilbury. These brand partnerships have contributed to the strength of our contemporary departments and attracted new customers to Nordstrom. Additionally, we had continued momentum in beauty, which has been among our top-performing categories for the 4 straight year.
Going forward, it is even more important for us to remain focused on the customer as our business continues to evolve. We've made significant investments to enable customers to shop seamlessly across stores and online as well as to grow our business through new markets.
With over $3 billion invested in capital over the last 5 years, we grew our top line by 50%, which was nearly $5 billion. We're also mindful of the importance for these investments to flow through to the bottom line.
While we're on track with our $20 billion sales ambition by 2020, our efforts to serve customers in multiple channels are having an impact to our business model. In response to changes in our business and current conditions, we've started to implement a number of opportunities to improve profitability. From a CapEx perspective, we reduced our plan by $300 million over the next 5 years. From an earnings perspective, our expenses have grown faster than sales to support our multichannel growth. We are taking action to moderate our expense growth over the next several years. Specific to 2016, we have planned expense savings of $100 million relative to our plan to [ph] year ago. This equates to a reduction of $50 million relative to 2015.
We are actively pursuing additional opportunities to improve profitability this year and in the years to come. We view this fluid an interim process as we stay focused on the customer and proactively ensure resources are aligned with the customer expectations.
I'll now turn it over to Mike, who'll provide more details on these changes with respect to our financial outlook.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Blake. First, I'd like to comment on our current results. We finished the year with our results in line with our expectations. Clearly, this was a difficult period, with industry sales declines and increased promotional activity resulting in compr
componenttext:
Thanks, Blake. First, I'd like to comment on our current results. We finished the year with our results in line with our expectations. Clearly, this was a difficult period, with industry sales declines and increased promotional activity resulting in compressed merchandise margins. As stated last quarter, we responded quickly and decisively to these trends with respect to inventory levels.
While we believe our inventory is current, we continue to monitor trends and make the appropriate adjustments to assure we remain price competitive and have the best product available for our customers.
On the expense side, overall operations were well managed, resulting in improved SG&A rate for the fourth quarter relative to our expectations.
Now I'd like to provide perspective on how we see our business evolving given current business conditions, our investment cycle and commitment to delivering top quartile shareholder returns. In evolving with our customers, we've made significant investments to enable customers to shop in multiple ways. This has resulted in market share gains, but also structural changes to our operating costs.  
For example, e-commerce now represents over 20% of our sales, a notable increase from 8% 5 years ago. This business model has a high variable cost structure driven by fulfillment and marketing costs, in addition to ongoing technology investments. With our increased investments to gain market share, along with the changing business model, expenses in recent years have grown faster than sales. As Blake mentioned, we are pursuing the following opportunities with focused efforts on increasing efficiency and lowering costs.
In technology, we are planning productivity improvements by focusing on fewer, more meaningful projects, such as a scalable merchandising solution that supports seamless integration across multiple channels. In addition, we are accelerating our efforts to re-platform our architecture to streamline development while reducing costs.
In fulfillment, we are assessing ways to improve efficiencies around delivering product to customers, which is expected to generate lower shipping costs. We are also refining our online assortments with a focus on unit profitability.
In marketing, we are focusing on improving our effectiveness across all channels. Consistent with our fulfillment efforts, we are measuring enterprise profitability of our total marketing spend. These and other initiatives are multiyear in nature. While we have successfully gained market share, we are also committed to growing profitability. With our investments moderating, we view 2016 as an inflection point of earnings growth improvement. We are focused on reshaping our business model and continuing that effort over the next several years to achieve our previously stated goal of mid-teens return on invested capital. As part of our regular communications, we'll keep you posted on our progress.
Moving to our capital investments. Our 5-year CapEx plan of $4 billion or 5% of sales represents a $300 million reduction in store investments relative to last year's plan. In 2016, we expect CapEx to be roughly $900 million, with 1/3 allocated to Canada and Manhattan. Technology and fulfillment, which represents another third, is planned flat to last year, a considerable production from the 35% annualized growth over the last 5 years.
Our investments in HauteLook, Canada and Trunk Club are beginning to pay off with over $400 million added to our top line growth in 2015. The dilutive impact of these growth initiatives has peaked in 2015, with expected EBIT improvement beginning in 2016.
In addition, our loyalty program is an enabler of growth to help increase our engagement with customers and attract new customers. With rewards members representing 40% of our sales volume, we look forward to expanding our program with a tender neutral offer in the second quarter.
Finally, I'd like to turn to our 2016 financial outlook. Our plan for earnings per diluted share of $3.10 to $3.35 assumes total sales growth of 3.5% to 5.5% and comps of flat to a 2% increase. Based on current trends, we remain cautious and have considered the impact of a continued promotional environment.
In the first half of the year, EPS is planned to decrease by roughly 30% due to the following: The impact of the sale of credit receivables; the impact of growth initiatives, including our third fulfillment center, which opened last August and new store pre-opening costs; and the shift of our anniversary event, which will span the second and third quarters in 2016.
In terms of our credit business, while we expect an initial reduction in EBIT from our revenue share reprogram with TD, we anticipate meaningful opportunities to increase earnings over time. Excluding the impact of the credit business, we expect improvement in retail EBIT growth, driven by the maturing of our growth investments in the operational improvements previously mentioned.
In closing, we continue to believe that we have the right strategies in place to profitably grow our business and successfully serve our current and future customers the Nordstrom way.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Trina.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: So on inventory, any areas of concern versus your plan coming out of the quarter? And can you elaborate on some of the actions that you talked about to remain price competitive? Just really help us to think about gross margin in 2016 versus the 92 basis p
componenttext: So on inventory, any areas of concern versus your plan coming out of the quarter? And can you elaborate on some of the actions that you talked about to remain price competitive? Just really help us to think about gross margin in 2016 versus the 92 basis points of contraction we saw this year.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Matt. This is Mike. I'll take the first part of the question as it relates to where we are relative to plan. We actually transitioned out of the fourth quarter under our original planned inventory. And as a matter fact, the change from plan to actua
componenttext: Sure, Matt. This is Mike. I'll take the first part of the question as it relates to where we are relative to plan. We actually transitioned out of the fourth quarter under our original planned inventory. And as a matter fact, the change from plan to actual at the end was consistent with the drop in sales relative to plan. So we felt like we would respond appropriately to keep those inventories in line. Now clearly, it's still as little penny [ph] was out there and we're keeping a very close eye on it. But the aging is in a good place and the levels relative to the investments we're making and our growth initiatives are in the right place as well. In terms of pricing, I'll let Pete take that.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I guess, what I'd say about it for us, the promotional and clearance activity drives some sales but not enough to make up for the reduced AUR. So that's where we had a lot of compression and then also what it does to our margin. So it's not a good si
componenttext: Yes. I guess, what I'd say about it for us, the promotional and clearance activity drives some sales but not enough to make up for the reduced AUR. So that's where we had a lot of compression and then also what it does to our margin. So it's not a good situation for us. I mean, there maybe other retailers that really benefit from a lot of promotional activity that drive sales in disproportion always. So we spent a lot of time trying to be transparent in collaborating with vendors talking about our desire to have newness really be the component that drives our sales and not the promotional activity. I think we worked to identify vendors that operate cleaner businesses. It's a difficult balancing act because you want to make sure that you bring the things that customers want, to have things just uniquely our exclusive for exclusive the sake. That doesn't work either bigger there are some areas that help mitigate some of the pressure. For example, our own label product, what we call Nordstrom product group, it's to grow part of our business. We had a really good year with Nordstrom product group, and I think that's the way we can control and does sell a bit more we go forward. And I think [indiscernible] say ultimately on our ability to keep our inventories in line with our sales trends is going to be the biggest factor in terms of managing markdowns and well. We've missed sales by a little bit the last couple of months. We're in pretty decent shape, and we're going to be disciplined this year about keeping those inventories down.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is from Oliver Chen of Cowen & Company.

componenttextpreview: I had a question about your earlier comments regarding profitability and fluidity. I was just curious about what you meant in terms of contextualizing? And what your meeting there? Is that a little bit different from prior thoughts on managing that balanc
componenttext: I had a question about your earlier comments regarding profitability and fluidity. I was just curious about what you meant in terms of contextualizing? And what your meeting there? Is that a little bit different from prior thoughts on managing that balance? And on the promotional front, should we -- could you just inform us by banner in terms of merchandise margin prospects as you think about Rack versus full-line versus online? And how the merchandise margins may look this year? You kind of been a leader in trying to rationalize the promotional environment. So are there any distinctions we should know about on a year-over-year basis in terms of the sales that you'll be running versus last year?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

componenttext: Okay. Well I think maybe, Pete, you can talk a little about the promotional -- what we're doing from a promotional standpoint then.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the rhythm of the business is the same in that there's a cycle to regular price selling that we pretty much are in lockstep with the industry based on those rhythms. When business is bad, it accelerates that clearance part of it. But the part
componenttext: Yes, I think the rhythm of the business is the same in that there's a cycle to regular price selling that we pretty much are in lockstep with the industry based on those rhythms. When business is bad, it accelerates that clearance part of it. But the part that we're talking about is promotional activity where a retailer will take everything that's on -- they had to offer. Something that's a week old in the inventory and something that's 8 weeks old inventory mark everything down. And that's what really erodes the margins. For us, we don't generate any of those events ourselves, but we have to be competitive for price. So if it's a price that's available for the customer and for all customers to maintain integrity and trust and confidence of our customers, we're going to match that price. So that's what puts the pressure on us in terms of and promotional activity. We don't have any more promotional activities in terms of clearance days or events, no more planned that than ever. I think we're probably packing that up even a little bit from this last year. So I'm not sure that answers your question. But philosophically, not much has changed in terms of what we've been doing for the last several years.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that helps. I think it has to do with the dynamic system in terms of the competitive landscape and matching. And were there any clues in terms of March margins going forward by Banner? Did you feel like certain banners had more opportunities for impr
componenttext: Yes, that helps. I think it has to do with the dynamic system in terms of the competitive landscape and matching. And were there any clues in terms of March margins going forward by Banner? Did you feel like certain banners had more opportunities for improvements than others?

componenttext: Yes, definitely the matching thing. To your point, certain banners, how that changed. I mean, you're talking relative to Rack business versus full-line -- full-price business?

componenttext: Yes.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think there's anything fundamentally different than what we've been dealing with really 4 years. We've been able to improve our margins mostly through increasing churn, leveraging inventory across multiple channels just being as efficient as we ca
componenttext: I don't think there's anything fundamentally different than what we've been dealing with really 4 years. We've been able to improve our margins mostly through increasing churn, leveraging inventory across multiple channels just being as efficient as we can. And that again, ultimately a over the long haul our ability to keep our inventory in line is what's going to make the biggest impact on margin.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Oliver, we have historically and really up until the more recent softness in the customer cycle have always had high end and increasing regular price business. And when you go through these soft cycles, when the industry has too much inventory and there's
componenttext: Oliver, we have historically and really up until the more recent softness in the customer cycle have always had high end and increasing regular price business. And when you go through these soft cycles, when the industry has too much inventory and there's competitive pricing, that's where we're feeling the biggest pitch. And so keep being very rigorous about controlling those inventories and about ensuring that we come out of this as we have come out of this before in a good place where we're sure that future profits will be better.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

componenttext: The next question is from Neely Tamminga of Piper Jaffray.

So is that -- is there a product execution there do you think going on a little bit in terms of the slacking newness having quite that risks going off the riskier? Or is there something else you think related to the consumer related to that Rack versus full-line? Any sort of insights you have between those 2 banners so far this year will be helpful.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: So really, about current trends. Ultimately, is it really consumer led? Or is about missed opportunities? From our own stores, we feel like you're lacking maybe a little bit in designer as well as in resort. It just feels like you're a little bit weaker t
componenttext: So really, about current trends. Ultimately, is it really consumer led? Or is about missed opportunities? From our own stores, we feel like you're lacking maybe a little bit in designer as well as in resort. It just feels like you're a little bit weaker this year versus last year. And I guess what we're trying to figure out is, is this something we can pick out that's product newness actually evolves at full-line? Or is there consumer issue? And could you comment a little bit more on that issue related to Rack versus full-line type trends?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't -- well, the product issues -- and actually, we're just discussing that as we're flying back from New York fashion week today. One of the nice things about industry, there's always optimism about new things coming out there and people are excited
componenttext: I don't -- well, the product issues -- and actually, we're just discussing that as we're flying back from New York fashion week today. One of the nice things about industry, there's always optimism about new things coming out there and people are excited to get it in front of customers. And there's evidence offer our business of pockets where business is really get because those new things that are common and then will they are comments about being off, that's actually not true for us. Our designer and handbag are pretty good even through some very challenging times. Apparels had a little bit of pressure, but I think there's a lot of things for us to be excited about. And that translates I think to excitement for our customers. So I think that's an excuse, you won't find us using. It's just a continuous matter of us trying to keep the focus on new product falling in. It's going to ebb and flow a little bit but as long as we can keep our inventories in line a don't think it's good to be a perfect problem. The Rack on the other hand, they benefit a lot of ways from some tough business out there because it means there's an excess of potentially really good product that we could get at great prices. And because we've got these great relationships with vendors, we can pass the savings along to customers. So I think that the difficult part is when you take -- when retailers or vendors take a price promotion on everything that they sell, they just -- they lessened the desirability of a product of why people pay price for. I think that's going to be an insidious part of what happens year maybe The Street the really good long-term decisions for health of the brand or even the trend. So that's something that we can't entirely control but. Obviously, we talked to vendors a lot about. I think one advantage that Nordstrom has people recognize out there, vendors recognize out there that we do run a good full-price business that does motivate our customers, and I think ultimately they like doing business with us because of that.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Lorraine Hutchinson of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: The next question is from Lorraine Hutchinson of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was just hoping to get a little more information on the cost cuts. I believe you said $50 million incremental for '16. What were you able to do so quickly? And then where do you see the opportunity for maybe the rest of this year, but also for '17 and '
componenttext: I was just hoping to get a little more information on the cost cuts. I believe you said $50 million incremental for '16. What were you able to do so quickly? And then where do you see the opportunity for maybe the rest of this year, but also for '17 and '18 in terms of trimming operating expenses?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Lorraine. Yes, this is Mike. In terms of that, I think that lines up very well to the 3 areas that we discussed in the overall approach to the changes in our business model, and that's in the areas of technology, supply chain and marketing. And I'm
componenttext: Sure, Lorraine. Yes, this is Mike. In terms of that, I think that lines up very well to the 3 areas that we discussed in the overall approach to the changes in our business model, and that's in the areas of technology, supply chain and marketing. And I'm not going to get into a lot of detail there. But suffice it to say, over the last several years, we've clearly been investing aggressively to grow our business. We've grown our business successfully. It's a new channel that is being built out that is still in the relatively early stages of its process, and I think we've reached an inflection point where after going it to the level we have, that we're spending a little bit more time focused on then how to turn a lot of that growth into some more profit. And I would say that is the common theme that you're going to hear from us as we talked about reductions without getting into anything overly specific. But clearly, we're seeing a -- what has been a very noticeable change in our business model. I think one of our slides indicated by the end of this decade that we're going to have a large proportion of our business, about 30% being done online. That's all the way from 5% than it was back in 2005. And that is a model that behaves enormously different than the mall-based model. And so we have a lot to learn about that, and we have to keep our lens on as it relates to how the customer sees us and how the customer wants to be served but at the same time, we have to do it effectively. And so that would be the theme and that will be the theme that we'll be sharing with you as we go forward.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

componenttext: The next question is from Joan Payson of Barclays.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you talk a little bit about the Nordstrom Rack stores? Comps have been negative now through most of the year. Maybe talk a bit about what you think that reflects, whether it's online cannibalization or competitive pressures? And does it create any c
componenttext: Could you talk a little bit about the Nordstrom Rack stores? Comps have been negative now through most of the year. Maybe talk a bit about what you think that reflects, whether it's online cannibalization or competitive pressures? And does it create any concern around the target for 300 stores longer term?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Blake, you want to take that, please?
componenttext: Sure. Blake, you want to take that, please?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Joan, this is Blake. The Rack brick-and-mortar part, the comp improved as the quarter -- the fourth quarter went on, the year went on. But no question, the first half or the first 3 quarters of the year, they were obviously running below our plans.
componenttext: Sure, Joan, this is Blake. The Rack brick-and-mortar part, the comp improved as the quarter -- the fourth quarter went on, the year went on. But no question, the first half or the first 3 quarters of the year, they were obviously running below our plans. And we shared with you both the full-price and off-price multichannel numbers, and that's something we've been talking about at least from a full-price point of view for a couple of years. Because most importantly, that's how the customer views the business and that's the how the customer shops. So we're trying to be clear about what that store businesses and what the online off-price businesses as well. We really look at it as an off-price multichannel business. And so for the year in the multichannel, I mentioned that was up 14% from a comp point of view, that's 4.3 for the quarter. Multichannel up price was up 12 and comp was up 3.6. So when we look at it in that regard, we're definitely gaining market share from our capacitors. The new Rack growth, which is the second part of your question, continues to be highly productive stores with terrific returns for our shareholders' investment. And so we feel good about this juncture, that 300 store commitment roughly that we talked about by the year 2020. Those lead times are short, so we can react to that quickly. We have 24 stores I believe slated to open in 2016. And again, we feel good about the off-price part of our business and the full-price part of it. And so we think there's a good balance between the full-price and off-price, and we're continuing nearing with that Rack growth.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Ed Yruma of KeyBanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: The next question is from Ed Yruma of KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: The decision to moderate the increases in tax spending, do you think that it will overtime reduce the level of growth in the online business? Or are you able to kind of drive in your [indiscernible] at this stage similar growth by making more targeted inv
componenttext: The decision to moderate the increases in tax spending, do you think that it will overtime reduce the level of growth in the online business? Or are you able to kind of drive in your [indiscernible] at this stage similar growth by making more targeted investments? And I guess, the follow up is how would you kind of ascertain the return on some of these step-up investments over the past couple of years?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. This is Mike. In terms of moderate the investment, I would just give you a little context that over the last 5 years, that investment pool was grown at an average of 35% a year and it's up to about $260 million, $270 million in terms of capital inve
componenttext: Sure. This is Mike. In terms of moderate the investment, I would just give you a little context that over the last 5 years, that investment pool was grown at an average of 35% a year and it's up to about $260 million, $270 million in terms of capital investment. So we've made a really, really big commitment there. And I think part of what we've learned along that journey is that we could likely be more productive with that capital, and we highlighted a couple of things that we believe long-term are going to generate a lot of value. One is having a scalable inventory management tool that can support as well past $20 billion and can support multichannel. And the second is to rearchitect how we think about our technology. So as we want to add new features and new applications, can do it the efficiently and cost-effectively. And we think over the long run, that's going to have big payback. In terms of the returns to the past, we've had some projects that have delivered some great returns and some that haven't. That, by the way, is part of the business. It's a test and learn and iterate business. But that being said, as I think over the last several years, we've learned that. We can -- we do it better. And at this point, we don't feel that the moderation [indiscernible] growth in that channel.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Kimberly Greenberger of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: The next question is from Kimberly Greenberger of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask about inventory. Mike, I think you indicated that the 12% increase in inventory at the end of the quarter was below your original plan. I'm wondering is there an opportunity to further reduce the inventory growth in 2016? I think you've gu
componenttext: I wanted to ask about inventory. Mike, I think you indicated that the 12% increase in inventory at the end of the quarter was below your original plan. I'm wondering is there an opportunity to further reduce the inventory growth in 2016? I think you've guided to sales growth of 3.5% to 5.5%. And is there any possibility you might be able to get the inventory growth down into the range of the sales growth?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the answer is yes. We think we can in continue to improve our inventory turns and make our inventory more efficient. At this point, getting it all the way down to the sales growth maybe not practical because we still have a number of forward-looking
componenttext: Well, the answer is yes. We think we can in continue to improve our inventory turns and make our inventory more efficient. At this point, getting it all the way down to the sales growth maybe not practical because we still have a number of forward-looking investments that we need to make. We have store openings. We still have a pretty rapidly growing e-commerce business. And so you have to assure that you've got the right inventory levels to support that future growth. But that said, we do believe these opportunities to be more efficient.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Dorothy Lackner of Topeka Capital Markets.
componenttext: The next question is from Dorothy Lackner of Topeka Capital Markets.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just going back to the idea of newness in the stores. It seems like you have been bringing in a lot of new brands, particularly on the contemporary side and continued to do that. So I just wondered if you pushed that a little bit more in order to keep tha
componenttext: Just going back to the idea of newness in the stores. It seems like you have been bringing in a lot of new brands, particularly on the contemporary side and continued to do that. So I just wondered if you pushed that a little bit more in order to keep that uniqueness in the stores? Is that a way of getting around the overall promotional environment on bigger brands? And then just if you could talk a little bit about the new national marketing campaign that you've just started as also as a way of maybe driving traffic into the stores.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Pete. I mean, you highlighted kind of the balancing act that we need to try to figure out. And you can bring new brands in. That's great. That has its own risks. Brands can grow to be really huge businesses overnight. It takes a lot of time t
componenttext: Yes, this is Pete. I mean, you highlighted kind of the balancing act that we need to try to figure out. And you can bring new brands in. That's great. That has its own risks. Brands can grow to be really huge businesses overnight. It takes a lot of time to get it there. So we have some fairly big brands that had some pretty sizable decreases over the last year. I mean, the good news is we've got some new brands coming up that we think can fill that void. I mean, I think one of the messages we were able to send to market this past week is we have open to buy even though business looks pretty difficult because we are looking to replace some of these brands that are -- when we're troubled some of the promotional activity in the sales aren't get. So good news, I think of I attract a lot of people. Maybe the best examples that we have that other people don't. So Madewell, for example, J.Crew brand, is not available. It's something they sell themselves because they sell to was because they like the way they do our business, they like our customer and its been really effective. And you get insulated from some of these issues because it's not available in a lot of stores that are more promotional in nature. Topshop's been a version of that. Brandy Melville is a brand that's done really well for us. So there's good examples out there. And some of the things you talked about, some of more leading edge things around that and bury business. We're proud of our team in their ability to get the forging ahead ultimately our ability to give successful going forward is not by repeating and refining last year, but to try to find new things out there to buy and new things the kind stimulate customers interest. And that's really the -- our inspiration and our process going forward this year. And then you asked about the marketing campaign, and that was a little bit of a new deal that -- a new campaign for spring that Olivia Kim helped create for us. And It's interesting. It's cool. Probably the best thing about it is it just reflects an optimism and kind of cheerfulness, which really should be what our business is are about when you come into spring, when there's a lot of stuff going on out there that maybe isn't super cheerful and bright. But I mean, our job is to make shopping fun for customers and I think that's what that campaign really reflects. And so for at least the anecdotal evidence is customers really like that.

componenttext: Sure, Tracy. This is Mike. In terms of the health of the credit portfolio, it continues to be very strong. componenttext: Mike, could you give a bit more color on EBIT guidance for 2016? You mentioned in the release that x impairment charges, we should look for retail EBIT I think up or down 3%. From your earlier comments, it sounds like gross margins will be continue to be pressured while some of your SG&A savings, that actually might be closer to flattish on a rate basis. Just want to see if that is directionally right. And then my follow up still on EBIT is on the slide in your presentation, that calls out the $110 million EBIT impact from strategic initiatives next year? If you can just break that out for us between Canada and Trunk Club? And give us an update on how we expect those segments to ramp over time.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Yes, Paul. In terms of how you've framed the EBIT next year, I think that's directionally accurate. We didn't get any specific guidance on SG&A, but your comments are relatively close. In terms of the strategic investments, the $110 million, that's
componenttext: Sure. Yes, Paul. In terms of how you've framed the EBIT next year, I think that's directionally accurate. We didn't get any specific guidance on SG&A, but your comments are relatively close. In terms of the strategic investments, the $110 million, that's Canada, Trunk Club and HauteLook. That's the impact in this investments have a had combination of operating profits or losses plus any purchase accounting adjustments. That's an improvement in 2016 from 2015, and we expect that continue to improve fairly measurably over the next couple of years. We haven't specifically called it out. We haven't broken then down individually for purposes of this. But directionally, we expect to see improvement. And I think that aligns with my earlier comment that part of the improvement we are seeing is the maturing of some of these investments as they start to scale up and approach breakeven and then start to make some money.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let me just take it on at a high level, Michael. The first thing, which is pretty significant, is the impact of the credit card sale. Recall last year, we sold the business in October, which means we were fully earning 100% of our credit card earnin
componenttext: Well, let me just take it on at a high level, Michael. The first thing, which is pretty significant, is the impact of the credit card sale. Recall last year, we sold the business in October, which means we were fully earning 100% of our credit card earnings through the first half of the year going into 2016 to the first half of the year. We will be on the revenue sharing program. So that's having an impact. The second thing is -- and it's been a phenomena over the last couple of years as with the amount of stores that we've been opening, we have chain new stores opening in Canada. We have a number of Rack stores opening. We have a fair amount of pre-opening that sits in the spring that we don't get a lot of sales benefit from and then it kicks into the back half of the year. And so that's the other element. And then the third element we called out was the shift in the anniversary sales. So those are the big 3. In terms of specific margin guidance, I'm not going to get into that level of detail here on the call right now. But I think if you look at those 3 large directional elements, hopefully that will help you.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just have one question. On the expense opportunities in '16, you talked about trying to put inefficiencies around fulfillment. Can you just elaborate around some of the initiatives that you are undertaking within lower shipping costs and fulfillment cos
componenttext: I just have one question. On the expense opportunities in '16, you talked about trying to put inefficiencies around fulfillment. Can you just elaborate around some of the initiatives that you are undertaking within lower shipping costs and fulfillment costs?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Bob, I would say again, a lot of these go back to how we're -- how we need to continue to view the customer experience, not just by channel but across the enterprise and understanding how we can serve the customer on an enterprise level. And there's
componenttext: Yes. Bob, I would say again, a lot of these go back to how we're -- how we need to continue to view the customer experience, not just by channel but across the enterprise and understanding how we can serve the customer on an enterprise level. And there's a number of things we can do. Currently today, we fulfill out of multiple locations are there other opportunities for us to get more efficient at that. That creates not only additional labor costs, but it creates additional shipping costs because you're shipping multiple items for an order. We're also looking at how spread out we want our assortment to be because the more lower-priced items we have in it, the less unit profitability be gain. And so we're looking at a number of different things but I think it all goes back to the rapid acceleration of the business and us continuing to feed that business and gain market share and now we are learning an awful lot about how that business is behaving and how we can make it more productive.

componenttext: I guess, 2 quick questions. You mentioned private label or Nordstrom's own brand. And can you comment on the percent of total sales that represents today? And how much bigger it could be? And then given success of beauty, do you have any initiatives in the beauty category to take advantage of that great strength?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Pete. Traditionally, we run our own Nordstrom product group in our way with a very persisted percentage. As we've done more designer business in the last 15 years or so, it came down a little bit because that's the place we just don't partici
componenttext: Yes, this is Pete. Traditionally, we run our own Nordstrom product group in our way with a very persisted percentage. As we've done more designer business in the last 15 years or so, it came down a little bit because that's the place we just don't participate and also with beauty to talk about. So if those 2 areas are big growth vehicles for us, at some place we don't principate with our own label product. But with the, for example, percent by business, have what we call it and what is apparel, which has a large component of our own label and that's been growing well. It's a little over 10% of our business. It's not going to change dramatically from that but can we do some more? Yes. We can do some more, and we pretty much been doing it not as an entitlement program where SPJs going to be a certain percent of the business, it has to grow because organically it belongs and customers have responded well to it. So the good news id customers have responded well to it. We've got some good momentum in a lot of places. I mean, we've had like a kid's brand like Tucker and Tate were just in 3 years. I think they're doing [indiscernible] $50 million in there. So I think that's a good business for us and it's a good business. So we -- there's a lot of confidence and a lot of great results that were towards. So yes, we think we can grow it in modest ways in the next few years. Related to beauty, that's it. That's a really interesting business. And the thing is probably best about it is for customers kind of enter Nordstrom through it and the most amounts of trips come to the beauty business. It tends to attract newer, younger customers as well. And so when that business is healthy, it really helps the acquisition part of what we're doing. It helps the traffic in the stores. So I think what we continue to focus on there is making sure that we keep moving forward. And because we've been pretty successful there, we do attract a lot of interesting opportunities. And I think one of the things that's particularly good about that business is the diversity where it's coming from, because it's coming really all different price points the design and luxury part of the business is really strong well the new things we've introduced the strong, the different categories, we've got a good thing there. So I think you'll just see us continue to try to follow the customers interest they are and make sure that we're best in class in that classification.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

componenttext: And if I could just ask one more. If you could comment on the environment. Obviously, the environment is tough particularly for pair retailers. I'm wondering what your take on it at this point or what might be the cost of this?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a great question. Some of this stuff is somewhat cyclical. But if we get into a position of trying to rationalize it based on external and macro factors that we can control, and that's not a very good place for us to be. So what we really try to fo
componenttext: That's a great question. Some of this stuff is somewhat cyclical. But if we get into a position of trying to rationalize it based on external and macro factors that we can control, and that's not a very good place for us to be. So what we really try to focus on are the things that we can control, and that's delivering great service for customers, having a great relevant experience for them with online and stores, seamless integration, new products for them to buy, kind of the excitement of what retailing can provide and we talked about in terms of marketing, kind of the hopefulness and cheerfulness of what this is about. And I think if we can keep that front and center, then we can continue to and customers business and gain market share. So that's why we're looking at it.
