headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greetings, and welcome to Nordstrom's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. At this time, I will turn the call over to Trina Schurman, Director of Investor Relations for Nord
componenttext: Greetings, and welcome to Nordstrom's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. At this time, I will turn the call over to Trina Schurman, Director of Investor Relations for Nordstrom. You may begin.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. Today's earnings call will last 45 minutes and will include 30 minutes for your questions.Before we begin, I want to mention that our speakers will be referring to slides, which can be viewed by going to nor
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. Today's earnings call will last 45 minutes and will include 30 minutes for your questions.
Before we begin, I want to mention that our speakers will be referring to slides, which can be viewed by going to nordstrom.com in the Investor Relations section. Today's discussion may include forward-looking statements, so please refer to the slide showing our safe harbor language.
Participating in today's call are Blake Nordstrom, Co-President; Mike Koppel, Chief Financial Officer, who will discuss the company's first quarter performance and the outlook for fiscal year 2016. Joining during the Q&A session will be Pete and Erik Nordstrom, Co-Presidents; and Jamie Nordstrom, President of stores.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Blake.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon. For the first quarter, we had a sales increase of 2.5% and a comp decrease of 1.7%, which fell short of our plan for a low single-digit increase. Despite our focus efforts to manage through this current environment, we are n
componenttext:
Thank you, and good afternoon. For the first quarter, we had a sales increase of 2.5% and a comp decrease of 1.7%, which fell short of our plan for a low single-digit increase. Despite our focus efforts to manage through this current environment, we are not satisfied with our results. Given these sales trends, our inventories were too high, which puts pressure on our margins and necessitate additional markdowns. Our team has aggressively addressed our inventory position, and as a result, we ended the quarter with inventory up 5% versus sales growth of 2%. For the balance of the year, our lowered inventory plans puts us in a much stronger position to manage the business more proactively.
In addition to our inventory management efforts, we're continuing to evolve our operating model to support our growth strategy. On April 18, we announced expense reduction efforts, predominantly here in our Seattle headquarters, of $60 million. This includes elimination of approximately 400 roles, which is about 7% of our corporate positions. This will improve our focus and execution and make us more nimble to respond to the business environment. Later, Mike will share more in our expense reduction efforts.
As we look at the balance of the year, we are actively implementing a number of initiatives to drive top line growth and improve the customer experience. On May 18, we're rolling out an expanded Nordstrom Rewards loyalty program that will allow all of our customers to earn rewards with or without a Nordstrom card. Our Rewards customers are many of our most loyal and best customers, spending 4x more annually. Today, only about 1 out of 5 customers are part of our program, yet their spend contributes roughly 40% of our sales. This opportunity to reward all of our customers is big. Over the next 12 months, our goal is to add 5 million customers to our program. This will drive more sales and trips and more importantly, it will enable us to better engage with our customers.
On the technology and e-commerce side, we are investing to create a more seamless experience across stores and all lines. This reflects continued modernization of our technology platform, including a scalable merchandising solution as well as service and experience features. These are significant projects. They account for 2/3 of our overall technology investments this year.
We're building on the continued success of our Canada expansion, with 2 full-line store openings in Toronto this fall. With Toronto representing the most productive market in Canada and one of the top markets in all of North America, we see this as a significant opportunity. We believe these stores have the potential, along with our international flagship in Vancouver BC, to be among our highest volume stores.
In the U.S., we plan to open our second full-line store in Austin, Texas, which is a dynamic and growing market. Our strategy remains squarely focused on serving customers on their terms. Knowing customer's desire and experience as both personalized and convenient, we are making improvements to enable our customers to shop seamlessly anyway they choose. In our stores, our overall focus is to improve convenience.
As a recent example, we enhanced the buy online pick up in-store experience by providing curbside pickup in all of our full-line stores. Additionally, we are upgrading our scheduling tool to support our team's efforts to ensure we have the right people in the right place at the right time. This will help improve customer service and productivity.
On the merchandising side, we are dedicated to having the brands customers want with a keen eye towards product differentiation. We know customers desire newness in fashion, but are being more deliberate with their purchases. We are seeing great results from our recent collaborations such as Ivy Park, Topshop, Madewell, Brandy Melville and Charlotte Tilbury. We will continue to introduce and grow relevant brands that are compelling to our customers while having limited distribution.
Moving to off-price. Nordstrom Rack represents an important channel for us to serve our customers and increase cross-shopping. Last year, 5 million new customers shopped at the Rack. This is meaningful because over 1/3 of our Rack customers will, over time, also shop in our full-price business. We've been pleased with our 6 stores that have opened so far this year. Their sales exceeded our expectations by more than 10%. We plan to open 15 more new stores this fall.
In closing, we recognize that the pace of change is increasing, so we're working diligently to evolve our business to best serve our customers. This means continuing to make the tough but necessary decisions that will ensure we are setup for continued success. We are confident that through our initiatives, we are competitively positioned to deliver the products and experiences our customers want.
I'll now turn it over to Mike, who will provide more color on our performance, along with details on the changes we are making to our business.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Blake. As we head into the balance of the year, we expect that uncertainty in sales trends will continue and have built that into our outlook. We are implementing comprehensive plans to ensure that we can execute levers around inventory, expense a
componenttext:
Thanks, Blake. As we head into the balance of the year, we expect that uncertainty in sales trends will continue and have built that into our outlook. We are implementing comprehensive plans to ensure that we can execute levers around inventory, expense and capital, all while maintaining our strong financial position. These plans also incorporate our commitment to liquidity and working capital needs by optimizing our inventory turns. We are aggressively prioritizing our resources to assure that every dollar spent is meaningful to the customer experience and will continue to challenge activities that are not.
Now I'll provide additional color on our first quarter performance. Our earnings per diluted share of $0.26 were below our expectations, primarily due to lower sales volumes and higher markdowns as we align inventory to current sales trends. Our results also included credit chargebacks and severance charges of $0.10. These chargebacks, which were significantly higher than planned, related to an industry change in liability rules that took effect last October.
In early February, we completed the rollout of our trip-enabled point-of-sale system. As a result, we have begun to see these chargebacks decrease and anticipate a smaller residual impact in the second quarter.
Moving to the top line. We had a comp decrease of 1.7% and total sales increase of 2.5%. Our full-price businesses, which include our full-line stores, Nordstrom.com, Trunk Club and Canada had a comp decrease of 4.3%. This softness was broad-based across stores and online as well as across merchandise categories, although we had notably tougher trends in jewelry and handbags as well as some of our larger volume brands.
On a positive note, we continue to see customers desiring fashion and newness reflected in consistent regular price selling as well as strength in our new and emerging brands. Our off-price business, including stores and online, had a comp increase of 4.6%.
In addition to inventory management, expense rigor is a key component of our plan. We are making strategic decisions to invest in our future growth while focusing on areas where we can further streamline. We continue to move forward with our emphasis on technology as a top priority, committing 1/3 of our capital investments.
In March, after considerable planning, we implemented a new technology operating model, which included adding technical expertise at the senior management level. We are confident that these improvements will lead Nordstrom's next phase of growth and innovation while continuing to optimize productivity and reduce complexity.
We are also executing on a number of initiatives to increase efficiencies across our supply chain and marketing functions. In our supply chain, we had an ongoing opportunity to improve the unit economics of product delivered to customers. We are refining our online assortment to greater focus on key brands and categories, while editing less profitable items. We are also improving our merchandise allocation process between stores and fulfillment centers, leading to a reduction in split shipments, lower cancellation rates and better in-stock positions, all of which ultimately improve our customer experience.
Similar to our efforts with technology, we are taking steps to increase marketing effectiveness across our enterprise. All of these changes are part of a broader ongoing efforts in improving our operating model. Through our actions, we expect to generate this year over $150 million in expense savings, inclusive of $60 million from our corporate realigning efforts.
We continue to explore further opportunities to maintain flexibility in responding to changes in business conditions and customer expectations.
Our third lever, in addition to inventory and expense discipline, relates to capital deployment and allocation. Given the changes we are seeing in our industry, we are in the final stages of a thorough review of our 5-year capital plan. This includes prioritizing our investments to achieve our stated goal of mid-teens return on invested capital. We will provide updates on these plans once they are finalized.
Now I'd like to address our financial outlook. In updating our plans for the remainder of the year, we feel that it's appropriate to realign our outlook given the uncertainty and trends and expectations for a continued promotional environment. Comp sales are expected to be between a 1% decrease to a 1% increase compared with our prior outlook of flat to a 2% increase. Our earnings per diluted share expectation for this year is $2.50 to $2.70 compared with our prior outlook of $3.10 to $3.35.
In closing, while the pace of change continues to accelerate, our commitment to serving our customers remains unchanged. With our experienced leadership team, we are confident in our ability to manage through this current cycle. We maintain a healthy balance sheet and cash flow that will support the best interest of our customers, employees and shareholders over the long term.
Now I'll turn it over to Trina for Q&A.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mike. [Operator Instructions] We will now move to the Q&A session.
componenttext: Thank you, Mike. [Operator Instructions] We will now move to the Q&A session.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Kimberly Greenberger from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Kimberly Greenberger from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, I'm wondering if, as you're reevaluating your financial target here for 2016, if you have taken another look at your 5-year capital plan to see if there might be an opportunity perhaps to cut back or redeploy some capital that you had previously tar
componenttext: Mike, I'm wondering if, as you're reevaluating your financial target here for 2016, if you have taken another look at your 5-year capital plan to see if there might be an opportunity perhaps to cut back or redeploy some capital that you had previously targeted for that 5-year plan?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Kim. Yes thank, you for your question. I did mention in our comments that we are going through a thorough review of the capital plan, which will result in a reduction of that plan. We haven't articulated that specifically yet. We're reviewing it wit
componenttext: Sure, Kim. Yes thank, you for your question. I did mention in our comments that we are going through a thorough review of the capital plan, which will result in a reduction of that plan. We haven't articulated that specifically yet. We're reviewing it with our board next week. And after we complete that discussion, we're happy to share it.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Totally understood. Are there any overarching strategies or any new insights that you're bringing to bear as you go through those discussions that might just sort of help us understand how you are evaluating your capital opportunities?
componenttext: Totally understood. Are there any overarching strategies or any new insights that you're bringing to bear as you go through those discussions that might just sort of help us understand how you are evaluating your capital opportunities?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think clearly, as we've been talking for the last couple of years, we're seeing a transformation in our business model. The e-commerce element continues to grow at a good pace, and the impact of technology and digital on the customer experience co
componenttext: Well, I think clearly, as we've been talking for the last couple of years, we're seeing a transformation in our business model. The e-commerce element continues to grow at a good pace, and the impact of technology and digital on the customer experience continues to accelerate. So that would imply our commitment to technology and fulfillment. And the things that continue to support that business is going to be something we're going to stay very strong on. On the other side, we continue to see traffic falling off in malls. And how we think about our store base asset, will probably require some level of adjustment. So I think fundamentally, that's how we're thinking.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Matthew Boss from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Matthew Boss from JPMorgan.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I just wanted to hear your thoughts on the roughly 10-point spread this quarter between Rack and full-line comps. What do you think off-price is delivering that full price department stores just seem to be missing? And as we think about the lower run r
componenttext: So I just wanted to hear your thoughts on the roughly 10-point spread this quarter between Rack and full-line comps. What do you think off-price is delivering that full price department stores just seem to be missing? And as we think about the lower run rate at NordstromRack.com this quarter, how do you accelerate traffic online? And anything to account for the moderation that we saw over the last 3 months?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Matt, this is Blake. I'll take the first part of that. I think, first of all, we would emphasize the online off-price part of that business, which is comprises of HauteLook and NordstromRack.com, and that's a newer business for us. It's been on a pretty s
componenttext: Matt, this is Blake. I'll take the first part of that. I think, first of all, we would emphasize the online off-price part of that business, which is comprises of HauteLook and NordstromRack.com, and that's a newer business for us. It's been on a pretty steep curve. We had a much more mature business on the full price side of it, and so that's been contributing greatly. And then the Rack has had a pretty consistent performance for some time. It, along with our other businesses, saw a little bit of softening in Q3 and Q4, and we were pleased in the Rack stores as we get closer to trend in Q1. It's more about our consistency with our trends and our plans, and there are some challenges and some headwinds in the full price that I think Erik can add a little bit to.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I can give you some context on the drop off in our NordstromRack.com business. 2 categories that I want to share with you. Number one, in looking at customer behavior, our conversion is up. Our customer acquisition, retention, AUR are all pretty much
componenttext: Yes, I can give you some context on the drop off in our NordstromRack.com business. 2 categories that I want to share with you. Number one, in looking at customer behavior, our conversion is up. Our customer acquisition, retention, AUR are all pretty much in line with our budget. Where we saw a drop off was on trips. We had fewer trips coming to our website last quarter. The second category, to shed some light, looking at regular versus off-price business on our NordstromRack.com site. Our regular priced demand is up in the mid-double digits and has remained healthy for quite some time. Where we're seeing a big miss is in our clearance and promo, promotional business. So we take lead from that is, number one, that the clearance and promotional environment is really noisy. There's a lot of excess product out in the marketplace. Certainly, easy to shop online. There's some heavy, heavy discounting going on, and we're seeing that effect in our business. Secondly, the customers are coming to us for newness, and our -- and a great experience, and that portion of our business remains pretty darn healthy. So that, looking forward, what gives us confidence and what we're determined to stay focused on is giving customers great merchandise to come and buy something new and give them a great experience. And I think it was in Blake's comments earlier, he mentioned some of the brands that were doing well with. That's more of what we see in our future. Something like Ivy Park that we launched, very limited distribution brand. We had great performance on that online and in our stores. The experience online was something we're pretty proud of and was a differentiated experience. And where we saw our weakness, it was in some very highly promotional brands that we had tough results with this quarter. So that's what we're seeing.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Oliver Chen from Cowen and Company.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Oliver Chen from Cowen and Company.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted your thoughts on what's happening regarding the price matching in the marketplace. You've done a great job really responding the kind of preferences consumers had around that. And also your comments on editing less profitable items. Could you jus
componenttext: I wanted your thoughts on what's happening regarding the price matching in the marketplace. You've done a great job really responding the kind of preferences consumers had around that. And also your comments on editing less profitable items. Could you just elaborate a little bit on the direction strategically what that implies? And if it's related to what you mentioned about larger volume brands being a little tougher? Just curious about what that means for strategy, the thesis.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, it's Erik. On price matching, it's -- the cause and effect is a little clear online in our stores, the price transparency that Internet provides. And we have been more purposeful for, let's say, the last couple of years of matching price on products
componenttext: Okay, it's Erik. On price matching, it's -- the cause and effect is a little clear online in our stores, the price transparency that Internet provides. And we have been more purposeful for, let's say, the last couple of years of matching price on products online really for big online retailers whoever they maybe because there is no originality to e-commerce. And that has served us well in gaining trust with the customers. We do not look to price matching or price promotion in any way as being a big strategic lever and a way of driving our top line. We look at price matching as a customer respect and a customer trust issue. That when a customer comes to us, they know that they're being treated fairly, and we think the clearest way of doing that and what customers expect is to not pay more for specific item when they're shopping with us. That's served us well in establishing that trust. We know from hearing our customers that they do have more confidence in our pricing than even just a couple of weeks -- couple of years ago. But strategically, where we're looking to win long term is at full price, is with newness, which as I mentioned, I think is increasingly with more limited distributed brands that really excite the fashion customer and gets them to look for something new.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Oliver, the second part of your question on the unit profitability. There's a couple of elements to that. One is just better understanding the breadth of our assortment. One of the ways that we've been able to expand and grow our online business is to exp
componenttext: Oliver, the second part of your question on the unit profitability. There's a couple of elements to that. One is just better understanding the breadth of our assortment. One of the ways that we've been able to expand and grow our online business is to expanding the assortment and at the same time, we also found that through expansion, some of our price points got to some lower levels that it becomes more difficult to make money on. So we're evaluating that. We've also done a lot of work to eliminate split shipments. Clearly, if you have to pay a delivery charge on a split shipment, it costs you more than if it goes in 1 shipment. So as we've grown and learn more about this business, we're finding ways to be more diligent specific about understanding those levers and making some progress on that.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Dorothy Lackner from Topeka Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Dorothy Lackner from Topeka Capital Markets.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wondered if you could talk a little bit about some of the other strengths or maybe weaknesses in the assortment and some of the things that you're doing to continue to bring that newness to the customer, whether it be through expanding Madewell, brin
componenttext: Just wondered if you could talk a little bit about some of the other strengths or maybe weaknesses in the assortment and some of the things that you're doing to continue to bring that newness to the customer, whether it be through expanding Madewell, bringing an Ivy Park? Or also you've had so much success with Nordstrom product group product recently, I just wondered if you could maybe speak to the changes that you're making to the assortment to continue to excite the customer?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Pete. You answered that question well. Actually, those are all things that we're doing. So I think the thing that should be kind of hopeful promising to all is we still have good examples of product that comes in and performs exceedingly well. It'
componenttext: This is Pete. You answered that question well. Actually, those are all things that we're doing. So I think the thing that should be kind of hopeful promising to all is we still have good examples of product that comes in and performs exceedingly well. It's not like there's a malaise over everything no matter what. It's just that's not the case. We've had good success as we talked about with Topshop that continues on; Brandy Melville, it's been really good; Madewell; Charlotte Tilbury; Ivy Park. Anywhere where we can work with the brand to do something, not necessarily entirely exclusive but somewhat limited to our stores around the brand that a customer has confidence and interest in, that's a great formula for us. The thing that we have going for us is we've had some success with these things. Our people an industry that's interested in working with us and we're big enough where we can create some special programs that it can be the pretty compelling to a vendor. So we found that most of our talks with the brands and the vendors have been positive about the things that we can work on together to help us stimulate interest with the customer. So we continue on with that journey. We're going to be pragmatic and conservative with our plans. We're going to be aggressive about trying to figure out new ways to get customers excited.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Does that mean that you pulled back on some maybe bigger brands that are very heavily promoted in order to kind of get out of that whole frenzy?
componenttext: Does that mean that you pulled back on some maybe bigger brands that are very heavily promoted in order to kind of get out of that whole frenzy?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, it was alluded to in what Mike and Erik talked about. There's some businesses that we've been in whether it's specific item or brand that might be pretty good for the top line but over time, it may not be particularly good for the bottom line.
componenttext: Yes. Well, it was alluded to in what Mike and Erik talked about. There's some businesses that we've been in whether it's specific item or brand that might be pretty good for the top line but over time, it may not be particularly good for the bottom line. So we've got to reconcile those issues. And you've heard us mention, there's some big brands that we had that had some precipitous decline. A lot of that's related to promotion and how that adversely impacted background with our customers. So yes, I mean, the good news is if you're a buyer here at Nordstrom, that creates some offer to buy. It creates an opportunity to try some new vendors, some new programs, some new things. And so brands are important part of what we do. But if they're offering and the way things are going with certain brands are damaging our brand, then obviously we've got to figure out alternatives and different things to try, so that's part of it. You heard about these brands. You mentioned our own label product the Nordstrom product group, which has been really pretty strong for us relatively as well, so we will continue on that path.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Stephen Grambling from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Stephen Grambling from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016

componenttext: I guess, just one quick follow-up to Oliver's question. Are you seeing any change in the percentage of transactions that are actually price matched in store?

componenttext: It's a good question. Jamie, do you know that?

componenttext: [indiscernible] we don't know that exact number at the moment.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sounds good. I guess, you also mentioned the more promotional environment. How much of that is being driven by kind of the traditional competitors, traditional promotional cadence versus either brands now trying to go direct or even e-commerce? Are there
componenttext: Sounds good. I guess, you also mentioned the more promotional environment. How much of that is being driven by kind of the traditional competitors, traditional promotional cadence versus either brands now trying to go direct or even e-commerce? Are there any kind of mitigating factors you have from brands going direct?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's, Pete. It's both. It's the traditional competitors and the fact that all these brands are retailers as well. People find themselves in a tough environment. They're doing what they can to stimulate sales, and I think it's spread in customers for
componenttext: Yes, it's, Pete. It's both. It's the traditional competitors and the fact that all these brands are retailers as well. People find themselves in a tough environment. They're doing what they can to stimulate sales, and I think it's spread in customers for some I guess, that means price promotion is a lever that's going to really compel the customers. I think what you're hearing from us is and that's not the most compelling lever for our customers. So what can we do about that? Again, I think we're big enough where we mattered to brands, so we can have conversations about how to run a healthy business and the choices that we have. The other thing that we have going for us is brands like our customers. We've got a lot of the kinds of customers that they want to appeal to and we have could customer data. And we can be transparent about that with our brand partners. We can usually work towards solutions that are going to work well. So I -- we've got a lot of things going for us that I think puts us in a position where we can do something about this.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Paul Trussell from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Paul Trussell from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, could you just dig into the margins a bit more for us? Just given the current inventory levels, what kind of assumptions are you and we should be making regarding continued merchandise margin pressure into the second quarter? Also how should we thin
componenttext: Mike, could you just dig into the margins a bit more for us? Just given the current inventory levels, what kind of assumptions are you and we should be making regarding continued merchandise margin pressure into the second quarter? Also how should we think about the anniversary sale shift impact to 2Q and 3Q? And then moving towards SG&A, what are the adjustment -- given the adjustments that you're making, how should we think about the cadence of expenses? It certainly seems like it was still in -- at an elevated level here this quarter.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, Paul, thanks for your questions there. Starting with the margin pressure. I mean, clearly, we haven't specifically broken out those line items. But based on the fact that we are in what is a typical down cycle where demand is soft, we're going
componenttext: Sure. Well, Paul, thanks for your questions there. Starting with the margin pressure. I mean, clearly, we haven't specifically broken out those line items. But based on the fact that we are in what is a typical down cycle where demand is soft, we're going to keep the pressure on ensuring that our inventories are turning, they're turning healthy, we maintained liquidity and we continue to bring new goods in. So that will pressure margins. And we have made assumptions within our outlook that include that. As far as the a sale impact, the impact to the EPS is probably a couple of cents shift between the second and third quarter and about a 200 basis point shift out of Q2 into Q3 for comps. And just so everybody understands that every several years, our anniversary sale, the last week of that falls into the third quarter. This is a year where that happens, so you're going to see the shift that relates to that. In terms of SG&A, again we haven't broken that out by quarter or specifically by line item, but I will say that we've already begun to see the impacts of the things that we are talking about. We expect the impacts of those elements to continue to improve as the year progresses.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Lorraine Hutchinson from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Lorraine Hutchinson from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: How much of the product in the store would you say is limited or exclusive to you? And how big do you think that could get over time? If that will be the key differentiating factor for the stores, how much of the store do you think you could get that to?
componenttext: How much of the product in the store would you say is limited or exclusive to you? And how big do you think that could get over time? If that will be the key differentiating factor for the stores, how much of the store do you think you could get that to?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's Pete. Its limited. It's kind of a [indiscernible] of range. So I would say in terms of stuff that's relatively limited or completely exclusive, it's probably maybe 1/3 of our offer, maybe a little bit more. It's hard to say. The thing is we're s
componenttext: Yes, it's Pete. Its limited. It's kind of a [indiscernible] of range. So I would say in terms of stuff that's relatively limited or completely exclusive, it's probably maybe 1/3 of our offer, maybe a little bit more. It's hard to say. The thing is we're still a house of brands. And one of the strongest elements that we have to compel ourselves to customers is the breadth of what we have to offer and brands really lead the way for that. So I think it's important that we don't manage the [indiscernible]. It takes a lot of finesse. I think it's important that we are always out there in the market looking to buy the best of what the market has to offer and then we can kind of work as time goes on in how to be meaningful enough to that brand where we can have the collaborative thing that works well for both of us. So we're pretty open, but ultimately, we want to make sure we're doing this. We think it will be profitable overtime. So that -- we can work on that more and it's become more and more of an important issue as time has gone.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Neely Tamminga from Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Neely Tamminga from Piper Jaffray.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: The thing that list at your 2016 triple points event as kind of a proxy to your most loyal customers and their behavior. Are you seeing more stability on the top line performance on those kind of days or triple points versus what you just reported so far
componenttext: The thing that list at your 2016 triple points event as kind of a proxy to your most loyal customers and their behavior. Are you seeing more stability on the top line performance on those kind of days or triple points versus what you just reported so far this spring? And maybe is it the low kind of in-between events that are causing more of a comp to climb? We're just trying to get a sense of truly most loyal customers and how they are viewing and how they're behaving.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Neely. This is Mike. Thanks for your question. We still see the penetration from our Nordstrom Rewards customers at roughly the same level a little better than it was last year. In terms of the events, I wouldn't say that there is a material change
componenttext: Sure, Neely. This is Mike. Thanks for your question. We still see the penetration from our Nordstrom Rewards customers at roughly the same level a little better than it was last year. In terms of the events, I wouldn't say that there is a material change in how we're seeing event versus nonevent periods. I will say that our last triple event, the timing of it probably wasn't the best. And so we're making adjustments for that. We're super excited about the nontender. There's a couple of elements about the nontender program I think that gives us a lot to look for. One is, as Blake mentioned, there's an opportunity to engage in a whole another pool of customers and to bring them into our loyalty program. And we have seen over time a multiple increase of spend roughly 4x spend and 3x more trips of those that are engaged in our loyalty program. And then the other element of that I think more on the operational side, and that is we really learned about how to develop a good customer experience, as a matter fact, an outstanding customer experience as we went through the development of this tool. And so we're really excited about that. We're looking forward to our customers using it. We believe it's very simple to sign up and simple to use, and we'll further engage a lot more folks into our Rewards program.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mark Altschwager from Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mark Altschwager from Robert W. Baird.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nice sequential improvement in the Rack comp. Can you talk more about the drivers there? Just curious, to what extent did higher inventory trends first from full price perhaps boost conversion on your PT and Rack? And to the extent you're able to reduce f
componenttext: Nice sequential improvement in the Rack comp. Can you talk more about the drivers there? Just curious, to what extent did higher inventory trends first from full price perhaps boost conversion on your PT and Rack? And to the extent you're able to reduce full price receipts given the softer sales environment, would that be a potential headwind on the Rack store comp as you progressed through the year?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, this is Blake. It's hard to point to one thing that was material enough that moved those sales. As I mentioned earlier, we're working on a number of issues, so we did see a overall an improvement. Part of the Rack's mix is the full-line store transf
componenttext: Mark, this is Blake. It's hard to point to one thing that was material enough that moved those sales. As I mentioned earlier, we're working on a number of issues, so we did see a overall an improvement. Part of the Rack's mix is the full-line store transfer merchant you talked about, and that's up slightly because as we get this clearance, rises, markdowns rising we're getting almost kind of a clearance fatigue from some of the customers that are not as motivated on this merchandise, it's causing us to have -- take markdowns sooner and steeper, in some cases, declare it. That's moved up a little bit the Rack. The Rack has a balance of closeouts from our top vendors, along with this full-line stores merchandise. Again, we're just pleased overall but are included. We think we have taken the necessary steps with our inventory planning within the off-price division to be fluid for what's available in the market because there's more product out there and both to ensure that we're in a position of both in the buy and flexibility for what comes our way if more of full price channels both the dot com and full-line stores?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next cash and comes from Jeff Stein from NorthCoast Research.
componenttext: Our next cash and comes from Jeff Stein from NorthCoast Research.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of points really quick. First of all, I'm wondering if you could tell us what the comp store sales were for the buck and mortar stores only for full price, off-price? And secondly, since you entered Canada, we've seen some changes up there i
componenttext: Just a couple of points really quick. First of all, I'm wondering if you could tell us what the comp store sales were for the buck and mortar stores only for full price, off-price? And secondly, since you entered Canada, we've seen some changes up there in terms of the economic outlook with lower oil prices, higher unemployment and now it's -- there's some discussion about a housing bubble in Canada. Any concerns about how that might affect your expansion plans and the performance in stores you've opened far up in Canada?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Jamie. I'll start with the Canada question. Our entry into Canada was not really well. We are now 1.5 years into -- since we opened in Calgary. We opened our first international flagship in Vancouver last fall. We're also in Ottawa. As Blake menti
componenttext: This is Jamie. I'll start with the Canada question. Our entry into Canada was not really well. We are now 1.5 years into -- since we opened in Calgary. We opened our first international flagship in Vancouver last fall. We're also in Ottawa. As Blake mentioned, we're excited about the 2 stores we opened in Toronto this fall. Yes, there's been a lot of talk about different macroeconomic issues in Canada. I would tell you, we've not seen a material impact from those, particularly in Calgary, which has a big concentration around the energy industry. We may have seen a couple of slight impacts but overall, our business there remains strong. And really encouraged by the overall customer reception we've had to our stores and in our merchandise mix, in our service. So despite -- well, I think we've all read about Canada. We're really encouraged about both the medium and long-term future there.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Jeff, you mentioned, this is Blake. About future, future growth we're committed to 6 stores so we think we're in the best markets there. As we mentioned we got the 2 in Toronto this year and we have our final store, our third, which will be in Toronto
componenttext: And Jeff, you mentioned, this is Blake. About future, future growth we're committed to 6 stores so we think we're in the best markets there. As we mentioned we got the 2 in Toronto this year and we have our final store, our third, which will be in Toronto in 2017. We don't have any other plans. We're excited about these 6 stores. They're in the best spots and doing the best they can with the communities. I think there was in additional questions there.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ed Yruma from KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, first, on expanded loyalty program. How do we think about the gross margin impact? And is this reward going to be materially different than those that have the credit cards? And I guess, second you guys mentioned that you will look at store closu
componenttext: I guess, first, on expanded loyalty program. How do we think about the gross margin impact? And is this reward going to be materially different than those that have the credit cards? And I guess, second you guys mentioned that you will look at store closures. Will that be within the context of these explorations or do you have a cohort of stores that are underperforming that you would consider terminating them ahead of at least renewal?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Ed. This is Mike. In terms of the loyalty program, we have factored in -- we haven't broken out at this point specifically the impact to the gross profit, but we have factored that into our outlook. The nontender program has a lower value element to
componenttext: Sure, Ed. This is Mike. In terms of the loyalty program, we have factored in -- we haven't broken out at this point specifically the impact to the gross profit, but we have factored that into our outlook. The nontender program has a lower value element to it than the tender when does. And so we don't expect this to have the same impact from a margin standpoint, and we're certainly hoping that it has a very favorable impact from a loyalty and long-term sales benefit.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: And non-store closures we have closed a small handful of stores of the last several years, and those were really all tied to lease expirations and the expiration of covenants. All of our stores are profitable, we all make money. So it's really not to unti
componenttext: And non-store closures we have closed a small handful of stores of the last several years, and those were really all tied to lease expirations and the expiration of covenants. All of our stores are profitable, we all make money. So it's really not to untie the performance its tied to a at least a covenant expires, we take a look at the long-term future of that story and that shopping center. And in some cases, we found that by moving to a better location in that same town, that same market, like we experienced recently in Los Angeles, we moved from South Bay Galleria to shopping Center about 3 miles away and we're having really good results there. So we're looking at those individual markets. Nothing -- no plans to announce now, but we're taking a look at them and we think there's going to be positive opportunities overtime.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Michael Binetti from UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Michael Binetti from UBS.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a quick modeling question, Mike. The restructuring charges on the credit chargeback, how much did that account for the change in the guidance for the year? Could you help us just directionally to think about that as an incremental data point? And if
componenttext: Just a quick modeling question, Mike. The restructuring charges on the credit chargeback, how much did that account for the change in the guidance for the year? Could you help us just directionally to think about that as an incremental data point? And if I could as a quick follow-up. We were surprised to see kind of a large shift lower in the retail EBIT guidance given the relatively small 1 point change in the midpoint of the comp guidance. You guys historically had some advantages and fixed versus floating SG&A because of the big sales commission line in your cost structure. I guess the leverage point on SG&A really changed that much this quickly? Or can you walk us through some of the items that are delivering pretty hard with the new guidance versus the old?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thanks, Michael. First, the first part of your question, the impact of the restructuring charges and the credit card chargeback activity was $0.10 or $30 million of pretax earnings for both the -- primarily for the quarter and there's probably maybe
componenttext: Sure. Thanks, Michael. First, the first part of your question, the impact of the restructuring charges and the credit card chargeback activity was $0.10 or $30 million of pretax earnings for both the -- primarily for the quarter and there's probably maybe a $0.01 or $0.02 impact in addition to that for the year. In terms of the leverage point, I think what you're seeing is that we continue to invest in the long-term growth of the company, which is having an impact on our -- on the leverage of the company and primarily a lot of that is coming from the accelerated pace of the technology investment. Those dollars and for the development of the tools that we're putting into place and the foundations that we're building not only come to the P&L but they go to our balance sheet and then find their way to the P&L relatively quickly. So that's a big element of it. The other element this you may recall we opened the East Coast fulfillment center last fall. And so we're still absorbing the incremental impact of the cost of that asset. So I would categorize their ability to leverage going forward as being more about the overall investments that we have made from a SG&A standpoint and of course in addition to that, we're seeing some pressure on our gross margin.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: My question really was on the full-line stores comp decline, the down 7.7. Was just hoping if you could give some perspective. I guess, a lot of us think your small store base located primarily in a malls would certainly buck what we're hearing about othe
componenttext: My question really was on the full-line stores comp decline, the down 7.7. Was just hoping if you could give some perspective. I guess, a lot of us think your small store base located primarily in a malls would certainly buck what we're hearing about other mall traffic trends. So it's been obviously many years since you put up that kind of comp decline. You had a couple of more months now since energy and tourism has slowed. Do you have any more perspective on what's happening at your full-line stores right now?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brian, this is Jaime. I think it's been pretty well documented out there that the mall traffic overall has been soft over the last -- probably couple of quarters. We've seen some data recently over the last month or 2 that it was down approaching double d
componenttext: Brian, this is Jaime. I think it's been pretty well documented out there that the mall traffic overall has been soft over the last -- probably couple of quarters. We've seen some data recently over the last month or 2 that it was down approaching double digits. And we noticed that. We are in -- we're primarily in malls. And when we see mall traffic go down, it hurts us. And we can see that in certain areas of our business. Clearance sales is a good example of that. While our full price [indiscernible] price sales have been hanging in there, our clearance sales over the last quarter or 2 have really been down. And I think that jives drives with mall traffic being off. So we're looking at how can we, regardless of the mall that we're in, give that customer a compelling reason to make a trip to the store. Obviously, that starts with merchandise, but also it has to do with the kinds of services that we're offering. And we mentioned we're making big improvements in things like the buy online pick up in-store experience. Things that we're doing online to flow into the store and vice versa. And so we're encouraged by things that we have in our control to compel customers to want to go to the store and we're excited about starting to leverage some of the investments we've made over the next year or so and creating some of these new customer experiences.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greetings, and welcome to Nordstrom First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded.At this time, I will turn the call over to Trina Schurman, Director of Investor Relations for Nords
componenttext:
Greetings, and welcome to Nordstrom First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded.
At this time, I will turn the call over to Trina Schurman, Director of Investor Relations for Nordstrom. You may begin.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. Today's earnings call will last 45 minutes and will include 30 minutes for your questions.Before we begin, I want to mention that our speakers will be referring to slides, which can be viewed by going to nor
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. Today's earnings call will last 45 minutes and will include 30 minutes for your questions.
Before we begin, I want to mention that our speakers will be referring to slides, which can be viewed by going to nordstrom.com in the Investor Relations section. Today's discussion may include forward-looking statements, so please refer to the slide showing our safe harbor language.
Participating in today's call are Blake Nordstrom, Co-President; Mike Koppel, Chief Financial Officer, who will discuss the company's first quarter performance and the outlook for fiscal year 2016. Joining during the Q&A session will be Pete and Erik Nordstrom, Co-Presidents; and Jamie Nordstrom, President of Stores.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Blake.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon. For the first quarter, we had a sales increase of 2.5% and a comp decrease of 1.7%, which fell short of our plan for a low single-digit increase. Despite our focused efforts to manage through this current environment, we are
componenttext:
Thank you, and good afternoon. For the first quarter, we had a sales increase of 2.5% and a comp decrease of 1.7%, which fell short of our plan for a low single-digit increase. Despite our focused efforts to manage through this current environment, we are not satisfied with our results. Given these sales trends, our inventories were too high, which puts pressure on our margins and necessitates addition markdowns. Our team has aggressively addressed our inventory position, and as a result, we ended the quarter with inventory up 5% versus sales growth of 2%. For the balance of the year, our lowered inventory plans puts us in a much stronger position to manage the business more proactively.
In addition to our inventory management efforts, we're continuing to evolve our operating model to support our growth strategy. On April 18, we announced expense reduction efforts, predominantly here in our Seattle headquarters, of $60 million. This includes elimination of approximately 400 roles, which is about 7% of our corporate positions. This will improve our focus and execution and make us more nimble to respond to the business environment. Later, Mike will share more on our expense reduction efforts.
As we look at the balance of the year, we are actively implementing a number of initiatives to drive top line growth and improve the customer experience. On May 18, we're rolling out an expanded Nordstrom Rewards loyalty program that will allow all of our customers to earn rewards with or without a Nordstrom card. Our Rewards customers are many of our most loyal and best customers, spending 4x more annually. Today, only about 1 out of 5 customers are part of our program, yet their spend contributes roughly 40% of our sales. This opportunity to reward all of our customers is big. Over the next 12 months, our goal is to add 5 million customers to our program. This will drive more sales and trips and more importantly, it will enable us to better engage with our customers.
On the technology and e-commerce side, we are investing to create a more seamless experience across stores and online. This reflects continued modernization of our technology platform, including a scalable merchandising solution as well as service and experience features. These are significant projects. They account for 2/3 of our overall technology investments this year.
We're building on the continued success of our Canada expansion with 2 full-line store openings in Toronto this fall. With Toronto representing the most productive market in Canada and one of the top markets in all of North America, we see this as a significant opportunity. We believe these stores have the potential, along with our international flagship in Vancouver BC, to be among our highest volume stores.
In the U.S., we plan to open our second full-line store in Austin, Texas, which is a dynamic and growing market. Our strategy remains squarely focused on serving customers on their terms. Knowing customer's desire and experience as both personalized and convenient, we are making improvements to enable our customers to shop seamlessly anyway they choose. In our stores, our overall focus is to improve convenience.
As a recent example, we enhanced the buy online pickup in store experience by providing curbside pickup in all of our full-line stores. Additionally, we are upgrading our scheduling tool to support our team's efforts to ensure we have the right people in the right place at the right time. This will help improve customer service and productivity.
On the merchandising side, we are dedicated to having the brands customers want with a keen eye towards product differentiation. We know customers desire newness in fashion, but are being more deliberate with their purchases. We are seeing great results from our recent collaborations such as Ivy Park, Topshop, Madewell, Brandy Melville and Charlotte Tilbury. We will continue to introduce and grow relevant brands that are compelling to our customers, while having limited distribution.
Moving to off-price. Nordstrom Rack represents an important channel for us to serve more customers and increase cross-shopping. Last year, 5 million new customers shopped at the Rack. This is meaningful because over 1/3 of our Rack customers will, over time, also shop in our full-price business. We've been pleased with our 6 stores that have opened so far this year. Their sales exceeded our expectations by more than 10%. We plan to open 15 more new stores this fall.
In closing, we recognize that the pace of change is increasing, so we're working diligently to evolve our business to best serve our customers. This means continuing to make the tough, but necessary decisions that will ensure we are setup for continued success. We are confident that through our initiatives, we are competitively positioned to deliver the products and experiences our customers want.
I'll now turn it over to Mike, who will provide more color on our performance, along with details on the changes we are making to our business.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Blake. As we head into the balance of the year, we expect that uncertainty in sales trends will continue and have built that into our outlook. We are implementing comprehensive plans to ensure that we can execute levers around inventory, expense a
componenttext:
Thanks, Blake. As we head into the balance of the year, we expect that uncertainty in sales trends will continue and have built that into our outlook. We are implementing comprehensive plans to ensure that we can execute levers around inventory, expense and capital, all while maintaining our strong financial position. These plans also incorporate our commitment to liquidity and working capital needs by optimizing our inventory turns. We are aggressively prioritizing our resources to assure that every dollar spent is meaningful to the customer experience and will continue to challenge activities that are not.
Now I'll provide additional color on our first quarter performance. Our earnings per diluted share of $0.26 were below our expectations, primarily due to lower sales volume and higher markdowns as we align inventory to current sales trends. Our results also included credit chargebacks and severance charges of $0.10. These chargebacks, which were significantly higher than planned, related to an industry change in liability rules that took effect last October.
In early February, we completed the rollout of our chip-enabled point-of-sale system. As a result, we have begun to see these chargebacks decrease and anticipate a smaller residual impact in the second quarter.
Moving to the top line. We had a comp decrease of 1.7% and total sales increase of 2.5%. Our full-price businesses, which include our full-line stores, Nordstrom.com, Trunk Club and Canada, had a comp decrease of 4.3%. This softness was broad-based across stores and online as well as across merchandise categories, although we had notably tougher trends in jewelry and handbags as well as some of our larger volume brands.
On a positive note, we continue to see customers desiring fashion and newness reflected in consistent regular price selling as well as strength in our new and emerging brands. Our off-price business, including stores and online, had a comp increase of 4.6%.
In addition to inventory management, expense rigor is a key component of our plan. We are making strategic decisions to invest in our future growth, while focusing on areas where we can further streamline. We continue to move forward with our emphasis on technology as a top priority, committing 1/3 of our capital investments.
In March, after considerable planning, we implemented a new technology operating model, which included adding technical expertise at the senior management level. We are confident that these improvements will lead Nordstrom's next phase of growth and innovation, while continuing to optimize productivity and reduce complexity.
We are also executing on a number of initiatives to increase efficiencies across our supply chain and marketing functions. In our supply chain, we have an ongoing opportunity to improve the unit economics of product delivered to customers. We are refining our online assortment to greater focus on key brands and categories, while editing less profitable items. We are also improving our merchandise allocation process between stores and fulfillment centers, leading to a reduction in split shipments, lower cancellation rates and better in-stock positions, all of which ultimately improve our customer experience.
Similar to our efforts with technology, we are taking steps to increase marketing effectiveness across our enterprise. All of these changes are part of a broader ongoing efforts in improving our operating model. Through our actions, we expect to generate this year over $150 million in expense savings, inclusive of $60 million from our corporate realignment efforts.
We continue to explore further opportunities to maintain flexibility in responding to changes in business conditions and customer expectations.
Our third lever, in addition to inventory and expense discipline, relates to capital deployment and allocation. Given the changes we are seeing in our industry, we are in the final stages of a thorough review of our 5-year capital plan. This includes prioritizing our investments to achieve our stated goal of mid-teens return on invested capital. We will provide updates on these plans once they are finalized.
Now I'd like to address our financial outlook. In updating our plans for the remainder of the year, we feel that it's appropriate to realign our outlook given the uncertainty and trends and expectations for a continued promotional environment. Comp sales are expected to be between a 1% decrease to a 1% increase compared with our prior outlook of flat to a 2% increase. Our earnings per diluted share expectation for this year is $2.50 to $2.70 compared with our prior outlook of $3.10 to $3.35.
In closing, while the pace of change continues to accelerate, our commitment to serving our customers remains unchanged. With our experienced leadership team, we are confident in our ability to manage through this current cycle. We maintain a healthy balance sheet and cash flow that will support the best interest of our customers, employees and shareholders over the long term.
Now I'll turn it over to Trina for Q&A.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
