headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sounds good. So I guess you also mentioned the more promotional environment. How much of that is being driven by kind of the traditional competitors, traditional promotional cadence versus either brands now trying to go direct or even e-commerce? And are
componenttext: Sounds good. So I guess you also mentioned the more promotional environment. How much of that is being driven by kind of the traditional competitors, traditional promotional cadence versus either brands now trying to go direct or even e-commerce? And are there any kind of mitigating factors you have from brands going direct?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's Pete. It's both. It's the traditional competitors, and it's the fact that all these brands are retailers as well. Everyone finds themselves in a tough environment. They're doing what they can to stimulate sales, and I think it just depends on yo
componenttext: Yes, it's Pete. It's both. It's the traditional competitors, and it's the fact that all these brands are retailers as well. Everyone finds themselves in a tough environment. They're doing what they can to stimulate sales, and I think it just depends on your customer. For some, I guess that means price promotion is a lever that's going to really compel their customers. I think what you're hearing from us is that's not the most compelling lever for our customers. So what can we do about that? Again, I think we're big enough where we matter to brands. And so we can have conversations about how to run a healthy business and the choices that we have. The other thing that we have going for us is brands like our customers. We've got a lot of the kinds of customers that they want to appeal to, and we have good customer data, and we can be transparent about that with our brand partners. We can usually work towards solutions that are going to work well. So I -- we've got a lot of things going for us that I think put us in a position where we can do something about this.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Paul Trussell from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Paul Trussell from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, could you just dig into the margins a bit more for us just given the current inventory levels? What kind of assumptions are you and we should be making regarding continued merchandise margin pressure into the second quarter? Also, how should we thin
componenttext: Mike, could you just dig into the margins a bit more for us just given the current inventory levels? What kind of assumptions are you and we should be making regarding continued merchandise margin pressure into the second quarter? Also, how should we think about the anniversary sale shift impact to 2Q and 3Q? And then moving towards SG&A, what are the adjustment -- given the adjustments that you're making, how should we think about the cadence of the expenses? It certainly seems like it was still in -- at an elevated level here this quarter.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, Paul, thanks for your questions there. Starting with the margin pressure. I mean, clearly, we haven't specifically broken out those line items. But based on the fact that we are in what is a typical down-cycle where demand is soft, we're going
componenttext: Sure. Well, Paul, thanks for your questions there. Starting with the margin pressure. I mean, clearly, we haven't specifically broken out those line items. But based on the fact that we are in what is a typical down-cycle where demand is soft, we're going to keep the pressure on, ensuring that our inventories are turning, they're turning healthy, we maintain liquidity and we continue to bring new goods in. So that will pressure margins. And we have made assumptions within our outlook that include that. As far as the a sale impact, the impact to the EPS is probably a couple cents shift between the second and third quarter and about a 200 basis point shift out of Q2 into Q3 for comps. And just so everybody understands that, every several years, our anniversary sale, the last week of that falls into the third quarter. This is a year where that happens, so you're going to see the shift that relates to that. In terms of SG&A, again, we haven't broken that out by quarter or specifically by line item, but I will say that we've already begun to see the impacts of the things that we are talking about. We expect the impacts of those elements to continue to improve as the year progresses.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Lorraine Hutchinson from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Lorraine Hutchinson from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: How much of the product in the store would you say is limited or exclusive to you? And how big do you think that could get over time? If that will be the key differentiating factor for the stores, how much of the store do you think you could get that to?
componenttext: How much of the product in the store would you say is limited or exclusive to you? And how big do you think that could get over time? If that will be the key differentiating factor for the stores, how much of the store do you think you could get that to?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's Pete. It's limited as -- it's kind of a grip at the range. So I would say in terms of stuff that's relatively limited or completely exclusive, it's probably maybe 1/3 of our offer, maybe a little bit more. It's hard to say. The thing is we're st
componenttext: Yes, it's Pete. It's limited as -- it's kind of a grip at the range. So I would say in terms of stuff that's relatively limited or completely exclusive, it's probably maybe 1/3 of our offer, maybe a little bit more. It's hard to say. The thing is we're still a house of brands. And one of the strongest elements that we have to compel ourselves to customers is the breadth of what we have to offer and brands really lead the way for that. So I think it's important that we don't manage with a blunt instrument, it takes a lot of finesse. And I think it's important that we're always out there in the market looking to buy the best of what the market has to offer. And then we can kind of work as time goes on how to be meaningful enough to that brand where we can have a collaborative thing that works well for both of us. So we're pretty open, but again, ultimately, we want to make sure we're doing business we think it be profitable over time. So that -- we can work on that more, and it's become more and more of an important issue as time's gone on.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Neely Tamminga from Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Neely Tamminga from Piper Jaffray.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: We looked at your 2016 triple points event as kind of a proxy to your most loyal customers and their behavior. Are you seeing more stability in the top line performance on those kind of days or triple points versus what you just reported so far this sprin
componenttext: We looked at your 2016 triple points event as kind of a proxy to your most loyal customers and their behavior. Are you seeing more stability in the top line performance on those kind of days or triple points versus what you just reported so far this spring? And maybe is it the lull kind of in between the events that are causing more of the comps to climb? We're just trying to get a sense of your truly most loyal customers and how they are feeling and how they're behaving.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Neely. This is Mike. Thanks for your question. We still see the penetration from our Nordstrom Rewards customers at roughly the same level, a little better than it was last year. In terms of the events, I wouldn't say that there is a material change
componenttext: Sure, Neely. This is Mike. Thanks for your question. We still see the penetration from our Nordstrom Rewards customers at roughly the same level, a little better than it was last year. In terms of the events, I wouldn't say that there is a material change in how we're seeing event versus nonevent periods. I will say that our last triple event, the timing of it probably wasn't the best. And so we're making adjustments for that. We're super excited about the nontender. There's a couple of elements about the nontender program I think that give us a lot to look for. One is, as Blake mentioned, there's an opportunity to engage in a whole another pool of customers and to bring them into our loyalty program. And we have seen, over time, a multiple increase in spend, roughly 4x spend and 3x more trips of those that are engaged in our loyalty program. And the other element of it was, I think, more on an operational side, and that is we really learned a lot about how to develop a good customer experience, as a matter fact, an outstanding customer experience as we went through the development of this tool. And so we're really excited about that. We're looking forward to our customers using it. We believe it's very simple to sign up and simple to use, and we'll further engage a lot more folks into our Rewards program.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mark Altschwager from Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mark Altschwager from Robert W. Baird.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nice sequential improvement in the Rack comp. Can you talk more about the drivers there? Just curious, to what extent did higher inventory transfers from full-price perhaps boost conversion on your PT and Rack? And to the extent you're able to reduce full
componenttext: Nice sequential improvement in the Rack comp. Can you talk more about the drivers there? Just curious, to what extent did higher inventory transfers from full-price perhaps boost conversion on your PT and Rack? And to the extent you're able to reduce full-price receipts given the softer sales environment, would that be a potential headwind on the Rack store comp as you progress through the year?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, this is Blake. It's hard to point to one thing that was material enough that moved those sales. As I mentioned earlier, we're working on a number of issues. We did see overall an improvement. Part of the Rack's mix is the full-line store transfer me
componenttext: Mark, this is Blake. It's hard to point to one thing that was material enough that moved those sales. As I mentioned earlier, we're working on a number of issues. We did see overall an improvement. Part of the Rack's mix is the full-line store transfer merchant, as we talked about, and that's up slightly because as we get this clearance, rises -- markdowns rise, and we're getting almost kind of a clearance fatigue from some of the customers that are not as motivated on this merchandise. It's causing us to have -- to take markdowns sooner and steeper, in some cases, to clear it. That's moved up a little bit with the Rack. The Rack has a balance of closeouts from our top vendors, along with this full-line store merchandise. Again, we're just pleased overall that it improved. We think we are taking the necessary steps with our inventory planning within the off-price division to be fluid for both what's available in the market, because there's more product out there, and both to ensure that we're in a position of open to buy and flexibility for what comes our way from our full-price channels, both in dot com and full-line stores?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next questions comes from Jeff Stein from NorthCoast Research.
componenttext: Our next questions comes from Jeff Stein from NorthCoast Research.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple ones real quick. First of all, I'm wondering if you can tell us what the comp store sales were for the brick and mortar stores only for full-price, off-price? And secondly, since you entered Canada, we've seen some changes up there in terms
componenttext: Just a couple ones real quick. First of all, I'm wondering if you can tell us what the comp store sales were for the brick and mortar stores only for full-price, off-price? And secondly, since you entered Canada, we've seen some changes up there in terms of the economic outlook with lower oil prices, higher unemployment, and now it's -- there's some discussion about a housing bubble in Canada. Any concerns about how that might affect your expansion plans and the performance of the stores you've opened so far up in Canada?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Jamie. I'll start with the Canada question. Our entry to Canada has gone really well. We are now 1.5 years into -- since we opened in Calgary. We opened our first international flagship in Vancouver last fall. We're also in Ottawa. And as Blake me
componenttext: This is Jamie. I'll start with the Canada question. Our entry to Canada has gone really well. We are now 1.5 years into -- since we opened in Calgary. We opened our first international flagship in Vancouver last fall. We're also in Ottawa. And as Blake mentioned, we're excited about the 2 stores we're opening in Toronto this fall. Yes, there's been a lot of talk about different macroeconomic issues in Canada. I will tell you, we've not seen a material impact from those, particularly in Calgary, which has a big concentration around the energy industry. We may have seen a couple of slight impacts, but overall, our business there remains strong and really encouraged by the overall customer reception we've had to our stores, in our merchandise mix, in our service. And so despite what I think we've all read about Canada, we're really encouraged about both the medium- and long-term future there.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: And, Jeff, you mentioned, this is Blake, about future, does it affect future growth in Canada. We've committed to 6 stores, and we think we're in the best markets there. As we mentioned, we got the 2 in Toronto this year, and we have our final store, our
componenttext: And, Jeff, you mentioned, this is Blake, about future, does it affect future growth in Canada. We've committed to 6 stores, and we think we're in the best markets there. As we mentioned, we got the 2 in Toronto this year, and we have our final store, our third, which will be in Toronto, in 2017. We don't have any other plans. We're excited about these 6 stores. They're in the best spots and doing the best that we can in those communities. I think there was an additional question there.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, first, on expanded loyalty program. How do we think about the gross margin impact? And is this reward going to be materially different than those that have the credit card? And then I guess, second, you guys mentioned you would look at store clos
componenttext: I guess, first, on expanded loyalty program. How do we think about the gross margin impact? And is this reward going to be materially different than those that have the credit card? And then I guess, second, you guys mentioned you would look at store closures. Would that be within the context of lease expirations or do you have a cohort of stores that are underperforming that you would consider terminating them ahead of lease renewal?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Ed. This is Mike. In terms of the loyalty program, we have factored in -- we haven't broken out at this point specifically the impact to the gross profit, but we have factored that into our outlook. The nontender program has a lower value element to
componenttext: Sure, Ed. This is Mike. In terms of the loyalty program, we have factored in -- we haven't broken out at this point specifically the impact to the gross profit, but we have factored that into our outlook. The nontender program has a lower value element to it than the tender one does. And so we don't expect it to have the same impact from a margin standpoint, and we're certainly hoping that it has a very favorable impact from a loyalty and long-term sales benefit.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: And on store closures, we have closed a small handful of stores over the last several years, and those were really all tied to lease expirations and the expiration of covenants. All of our stores are profitable, we all make money. So it's really not tied
componenttext: And on store closures, we have closed a small handful of stores over the last several years, and those were really all tied to lease expirations and the expiration of covenants. All of our stores are profitable, we all make money. So it's really not tied to performance, it's tied to when a lease or a covenant expires. We take a look at the long-term future of that story and that shopping center. And in some cases, we found that by moving to a better location in that same town, in that same market, like we experienced recently in Los Angeles, we moved from South Bay Galleria to Del Amo Shopping Center about 3 miles away, and we're having really good results there. And so we're looking at those individual markets. Nothing -- no plans to announce now, but we're taking a look at them, and we think there's going to be positive opportunities over time.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Michael Binetti from UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Michael Binetti from UBS.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a quick modeling question, Mike. The restructuring charges on the credit chargeback, how much did that account for the change in the guidance for the year? Could you help us just directionally think about that as an incremental data point? And then i
componenttext: Just a quick modeling question, Mike. The restructuring charges on the credit chargeback, how much did that account for the change in the guidance for the year? Could you help us just directionally think about that as an incremental data point? And then if I could ask a quick follow-up. We were surprised to see kind of a large shift lowering the retail EBIT guidance given the relatively small 1 point change in the midpoint of the comp guidance. You guys have historically had some advantages in fixed versus floating SG&A because of the big sales commission line in your cost structure. I mean, has the leverage point on SG&A really changed that much this quickly? Or can you walk us through some of the items that seem to be delevering pretty hard in the new guidance versus the old?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thanks, Michael. First, the first part of your question, the impact of the restructuring charges and the credit card chargeback activity was $0.10 or $30 million of pretax earnings for both the -- primarily for the quarter, and there's probably mayb
componenttext: Sure. Thanks, Michael. First, the first part of your question, the impact of the restructuring charges and the credit card chargeback activity was $0.10 or $30 million of pretax earnings for both the -- primarily for the quarter, and there's probably maybe a $0.01 or $0.02 impact in addition to that for the year. In terms of the leverage point, I think what you're seeing is that we continue to invest in the long-term growth of the company, which is having an impact on our -- on the leverage of the company, and primarily, a lot of that is coming from the accelerated pace of the technology investment. Those dollars for the development of the tools that we're putting into place and the foundations that we're building, not only come to the P&L, but they go to our balance sheet and then find their way through the P&L relatively quickly. So that's a big element of it. The other element is, you may recall, we opened the East Coast fulfillment center last fall. And so we're still absorbing the incremental impact of the cost of that asset. So I would categorize the ability to leverage going forward as being more about the overall investments that we have made from an SG&A standpoint. And of course, in addition to that, we're seeing some pressure on our gross margin.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: My question really was on the full-line store comp decline, the down 7.7%. Was just hoping you could give some perspective. I guess a lot of us think your small store base located primarily in a malls would certainly buck what we're hearing about other ma
componenttext: My question really was on the full-line store comp decline, the down 7.7%. Was just hoping you could give some perspective. I guess a lot of us think your small store base located primarily in a malls would certainly buck what we're hearing about other mall traffic trends. So it's been obviously many years since you've put up that kind of comp decline. You've had a couple more months now since energy and tourism have slowed. Do you have any more perspective on what's happening at your full-line stores right now?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Brian, this is Jamie. I think it's been pretty well documented out there that mall traffic overall has been soft over the last, probably, couple quarters. We've seen some data recently over the last month or 2 that it was down approaching double digi
componenttext: Yes. Brian, this is Jamie. I think it's been pretty well documented out there that mall traffic overall has been soft over the last, probably, couple quarters. We've seen some data recently over the last month or 2 that it was down approaching double digits, and we noticed that. We are in -- we're primarily in malls, and when we see mall traffic go down, it hurts us. And we can see that in certain areas of our business. Clearance sales is a good example of that. While our full-price regular price sales have been hanging in there, our clearance sales over the last quarter or 2 have really been down. And I think that jives with mall traffic being off. So we're looking at how can we, regardless of the mall that we're in, give the customer a compelling reason to make a trip to the store. Obviously, that starts with the merchandise, but also, it has to do with the kind of services that we're offering. And we mentioned we're making big improvements in things like the buy online pickup in store experience, things that we're doing online that flow into the store and vice versa. And so we're encouraged by things that we have in our control to compel customers to want to go -- come to the store, and we're excited about starting to leverage some of the investments we've made over the next year or so in creating some of these new customer experiences.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greetings, and welcome to the Nordstrom Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. At this time, I will turn the call over to Trina Schurman, Director of Investor Relations for N
componenttext: Greetings, and welcome to the Nordstrom Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. At this time, I will turn the call over to Trina Schurman, Director of Investor Relations for Nordstrom. You may begin.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. Today's earnings call will last 45 minutes, and we'll include 30 minutes for your questions.Before we begin, I want to mention that our speakers will be referring to slides, which can be viewed by going to n
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. Today's earnings call will last 45 minutes, and we'll include 30 minutes for your questions.
Before we begin, I want to mention that our speakers will be referring to slides, which can be viewed by going to nordstrom.com in Investor Relations section. Today's discussion may include forward-looking statements, so please refer to the slide showing our safe harbor language.
Participating in today's call are Blake Nordstrom, Co-President; and Mike Koppel, Chief Financial Officer, who will discuss the company's second quarter performance and the outlook for fiscal year 2016. Joining during the Q&A session will be Pete and Erik Nordstrom, Co-Presidents.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Blake.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon. Over the past several quarters, our team has been actively addressing our inventory expense and capital as we align the current sales trends. In the second quarter, the team made substantial progress by bringing down invento
componenttext:
Thank you, and good afternoon. Over the past several quarters, our team has been actively addressing our inventory expense and capital as we align the current sales trends. In the second quarter, the team made substantial progress by bringing down inventory in line with sales. We're also pleased with our customers' response to the Anniversary Sale. This year marked one of the best events we've had in our history, with an all-time high in sales volume. The strength of our anniversary event, along with the team's inventory and expense execution drove better-than-expected results for the second quarter. Our anniversary performance reflected an improvement from our recent sales trends. We had a strong start to the sale, and the momentum continued throughout the event. Our sellthrough rates were at record highs, putting us in a clean inventory position for the second half of the year.
Customers responded favorably to newness, with shoes and beauty leading our results. As a reminder, historically, every several years, we have a shift in our anniversary event, which moves 1 week of the event into the third quarter. As a result, our comp decrease of 1.2% was unfavorably impacted by roughly 250 basis points.
On May 18, we achieved an important milestone with the expansion of our loyalty program. Nordstrom Rewards serves as a powerful tool to drive incremental sales and trips. Given more importantly, it gives us an opportunity to strengthen relationships with customers. In response to feedback for more flexibility in joining our program, we've expanded it so that all of our customers can earn rewards regardless of how they choose to pay. We're encouraged with the strong response. We now have around 6 million total Rewards customers who shop with us over the last year, up significantly from 4.7 million last quarter.
As we head into the second half of the year, we are focused on a number of initiatives to improve the customer experience and drive top line growth. In our Nordstrom brand, we're expanding our reach to serve more customers. We're building on the success of our Canada expansion with 2 full-line store openings in Toronto. On September 16, we will open a flagship at Eaton center, followed by another store in Yorkville shopping center on October 21. 
In the U.S. we will open a second full-line store in Austin, Texas on September 30. In our Nordstrom Rack brand, we open to open 15 stores this fall for a total of 215 by the end of the year.
Our merchandise strategy remains focused on providing our customers with newness. Our efforts to grow relevant brands that have limited distribution play an important role in creating excitement and tracking new customers. They now make up the majority of our top 20 fastest growing vendors, and we're continuing to expand the most highly sought-after brands like IVY PARK, Madewell and Charlotte Tilbury with new partnerships to come.
In addition to providing a differentiated product offering, we recognize that our customers desire of personalized and convenient experience. To meet their evolving expectations, we are making digital enhancements to better serve customers no matter how they choose to shop with us. We have several initiatives underway that include new mobile features, improvements to our website and enhanced selling tools.
In the second quarter, we've made ongoing improvements to our mobile app, including features that enable customers to shop their store of choice and shop for items they have done a visual search.
This fall, we are piloting a mobile feature that gives customers the ability to reserve merchandise online and try in our stores.
In closing, our ability to deliver strong anniversary results while realigning inventory expense speaks volumes to the quality of our team. We're proud of the team's high level of execution and remain committed to continuing this progress. Next quarter, we look forward to providing further updates on our efforts, including our extended loyalty program and performance in Canada.
I'll now turn it over to Mike, who will provide additional color on our results and our ongoing efforts improve our business models.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Blake. Our second quarter results are reflective of the ongoing efforts to realign our resources and priorities to customer expectations. This includes the progress we have made adjusting our inventory and expense, which had a positive impact on o
componenttext:
Thanks, Blake. Our second quarter results are reflective of the ongoing efforts to realign our resources and priorities to customer expectations. This includes the progress we have made adjusting our inventory and expense, which had a positive impact on our second quarter results. As we evolve our business model, we will continue to aggressively prioritize our resources to ensure that we can serve customers with high quality products and services while achieving profitable growth.
Our earnings per diluted share of $0.67 were ahead of our expectations driven by our strong execution of the Anniversary Sale, inventory management and expense control. We are also continuing to see benefits from the strategic growth investments we've made to fuel growth in new markets and e-commerce. These investments, HauteLook, our expansion into Canada and Trunk Club are expected to contribute over $1 billion to our top line in 2016.
Our full-line stores, Nordstrom.com and Trunk Club, had a combined comp decrease of 2.3%. This reflected an unfavorable impact of over 250 basis points from the event shift. The momentum of Nordstrom Rack consisting of stores and online continued with a comp increase of 5.3% on top of last year's increase of 6.5%.
Over the last several quarters, we have been aggressively adjusting our inventory plans as consumer demand has changed. We have a complex portfolio of businesses. And combined with the uncertainty of sales trends, our merchant and planning teams were making continuing adjustments. That high level of execution, combined with a compelling product offering for the Anniversary Sale, drove better-than-expected results for the second quarter. Our inventories are well positioned, current and in line with our sales trends. As a result, we are on the offense focused on bringing in the latest and most compelling product offering that resonates with our customers.
In terms of our broader efforts to improve profitability, we recognize that the shift towards e-commerce is having an impact to our financial model. As we accelerate investments to support changes in customer expectations, our expenses, particularly in technology, supply chain and marketing, grew faster than sales.
To address this, we are continuing to make operational changes to rightsize this trajectory. 
As we shared last quarter, we identified over 150 million in productivity improvements this year, of which roughly half has been realized to date. We are streamlining corporate headquarters and executed on a number of initiatives that will enhance the customer experience and improve our operating model.
In technology, we're on a path to modernize our platform and increase the productivity of delivering features that will improve the customer experience. For example, this year, we implemented new technology solutions that support our expanded loyalty program and online search engine. These modernized platforms enable us to serve customers in a more personalized and relevant way.
In supply chain, we've executed on several initiatives to improve operating performance. This included optimizing our supplier network for both inbound and outbound carriers, reducing split shipments to a greater allocation of merchandise to our fulfillment centers and editing out less profitable items online. 
A year ago, we opened our East Coast fulfillment center, which has the potential to double our fulfillment capacity as we scale for growth. For customers we serve on the East Coast, we've been able to speed up delivery times by over 30% with lower unit shipping costs due to the increased proximity to our customers. In continuing these efforts, we are further integrating Trunk Club's operations into the Nordstrom fulfillment network with completion expected by mid-2017.
In marketing, we are repositioning our organization to better align with the customer journey and our strategic priorities around customer, acquisition and retention. This includes strengthening our capabilities around customer analytics and digital engagement so that we can reach customers in a more efficient and cost-effective manner. Our expanded loyalty program demonstrates our efforts to rebalance our marketing resources towards a greater focus on personalization. This will help us better serve customers and increase their lifetime value.
In addition to the adjustments we've made to inventory and expense, we have reprioritized our capital investments to better align with changing customer expectations and strengthen our financial position. This resulted in a 10% reduction to our 5-year capital plan. Our reduced CapEx plan of $3.6 billion is appropriately balanced between store and technology investments. We have made a modest reduction to our Rack store expansion plans given the growth of our online business, which has doubled since the launch of NordstromRack.com a couple years ago. All of these efforts to improve our productivity will result in a more productive use of financial resources, which is beginning to positively impact our results.
During the second quarter, our cash flow from operating activities was $853 million, more than twice what it was last year.
Now I'd like to address our financial outlook. We have adjusted our earnings per share outlook to $2.60 to $2.75 from our prior outlook of $2.50 to $2.70. As we head into the second half of the year, we believe we are well positioned to manage our business while also being mindful of uncertainty in retail trends.
In closing, as our business evolves, we remain confident in our ability to serve customers in an exemplary way and achieve sustainable profitable growth. Through our ongoing efforts, we believe Nordstrom will emerge stronger and better positioned for future success.
I'll now turn it over to Trina for Q&A.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mike. [Operator Instructions] We will now move to the Q&A session.
componenttext: Thank you, Mike. [Operator Instructions] We will now move to the Q&A session.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Lorraine Hutchinson from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Lorraine Hutchinson from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was just hoping that you could give us some clarity on which of the categories you saw the most sequential improvement in during the Anniversary Sale? And how your modeling receipts for those specific categories coming into the back half?
componenttext: I was just hoping that you could give us some clarity on which of the categories you saw the most sequential improvement in during the Anniversary Sale? And how your modeling receipts for those specific categories coming into the back half?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Pete. We experienced some good success in a few categories. You heard us call out beauty and shoes, in particular. I think we've got categories within there. Boots were particularly good for us in shoes. In apparel, our denim business was strong a
componenttext: This is Pete. We experienced some good success in a few categories. You heard us call out beauty and shoes, in particular. I think we've got categories within there. Boots were particularly good for us in shoes. In apparel, our denim business was strong as were sweaters. In terms of how that impacts our inventory plans going forward, I think for us, we're really well served to try to keep our inventory plans conservative. We've been able to prove over the years that we can exceed sales plans with concerted inventory plans. And when you do that, I mean, obviously, it just -- it creates a good scenario for us in reducing markdown. So I think while we're happy about the sales results, we're very cautious not to over invest either our plans or just in a way that we're allocating inventory. So we're still thinking a cautious approach over [ph] the second half.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Matthew Boss from JP Morgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Matthew Boss from JP Morgan.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the Rack seems to be striking a really nice balance with stable brick-and-mortar and then outsized online growth, but the full-line still remains negative. What do you think off-price is delivering that the full-line's missing? And what's the best way
componenttext: So the Rack seems to be striking a really nice balance with stable brick-and-mortar and then outsized online growth, but the full-line still remains negative. What do you think off-price is delivering that the full-line's missing? And what's the best way to think about initiatives in place to drive better traffic at the full-line?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Matthew, this is Blake. We don't look at it as the Racks doing something that the full-line stores missing. Those are different businesses. There's some similarities, but we're making terrific progress within the full-line stores, and that trend improved
componenttext: Matthew, this is Blake. We don't look at it as the Racks doing something that the full-line stores missing. Those are different businesses. There's some similarities, but we're making terrific progress within the full-line stores, and that trend improved greatly in that second quarter. So the Racks been -- had a more consistent basis the last couple of years than the full-line stores. Although we've got a team on the full-price business, the Nordstrom brand, and we view it together, both the stores and the online as one business and it's over time, becoming more and more merged. So the customer doesn't view that as 2 different experiences. But that said, there are experiences that with product and experiences in the store online that the customers' desire is up and deems this good service. And it's a fluid thing, and we're working on a number of initiatives. And we're encouraged about on the Anniversary Sale, the feedback and response we've got and the opportunities we have going forward.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Matt, this is Mike. The one thing I would add to that is you have to look at the relative maturity of the online channel in the full-price sector versus the off-price, and we're one of the few that actually have an online offering off-price. Most off-pric
componenttext: Matt, this is Mike. The one thing I would add to that is you have to look at the relative maturity of the online channel in the full-price sector versus the off-price, and we're one of the few that actually have an online offering off-price. Most off-price is done in store. So I think there's a little bit of apples and oranges there in terms of comparing the 2.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jeff Stein from NorthCoast Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jeff Stein from NorthCoast Research.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Question on the service levels in the store. If you continue to see drops in same-store sales, are you making adjustments in selling payroll because obviously, your online business is more of a variable cost model and you've got that fixed costs in the st
componenttext: Question on the service levels in the store. If you continue to see drops in same-store sales, are you making adjustments in selling payroll because obviously, your online business is more of a variable cost model and you've got that fixed costs in the store. And if it -- we continue to see negative comps, obviously that is going to continue to weigh on your EBIT margins. But -- so I guess, on -- I'm asking questions. I'm also making a comment. Do you risk -- if that's the case and if you do adjust payroll on the downside, are you risking service levels, I guess, inferior service levels in store?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. This is Mike. I think the first point I would make there is certainly, a key differentiator for us is our service level. So we're very, very conscious of the sharing that we deliver that high level of service. But keep in mind in our regular-price b
componenttext: Sure. This is Mike. I think the first point I would make there is certainly, a key differentiator for us is our service level. So we're very, very conscious of the sharing that we deliver that high level of service. But keep in mind in our regular-price business in the full-line stores, that's 100% commission based sales force. So by its very nature, it does adjust to the overall level of sales volume activity. And certainly, we also ensure that we have the right level of staffing there to ensure that we can deliver the right level of service. So I think that's something that we prefer not to compromise.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Paul Trussell from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Paul Trussell from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: I apologize if I missed it, but did you give the actual comp for the Anniversary Sale? And also if you can just touch on the narrower spread between comp and overall sales growth this quarter.
componenttext: I apologize if I missed it, but did you give the actual comp for the Anniversary Sale? And also if you can just touch on the narrower spread between comp and overall sales growth this quarter.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Paul. We didn't break out the actual Anniversary Sale comp. In terms of the difference between the total sales and the comp sales, the reason it was so -- the spread was so narrow was at the end of every quarter, we're required to make a number of ad
componenttext: Yes, Paul. We didn't break out the actual Anniversary Sale comp. In terms of the difference between the total sales and the comp sales, the reason it was so -- the spread was so narrow was at the end of every quarter, we're required to make a number of adjustments that primarily relate to the timing of sales and the timing of returns at the end of every quarter. And because of the high volume of anniversary, that tends to be a higher adjustment at the end of the second quarter. It's basically timing and it's a GAAP adjustment, and that will reappear next quarter.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. That's helpful. And then just very quick follow-up. Could you just [indiscernible] margin in the second quarter versus your expectations coming in? And given when where inventories are now, how should we think about that line item in the second ha
componenttext: Got it. That's helpful. And then just very quick follow-up. Could you just [indiscernible] margin in the second quarter versus your expectations coming in? And given when where inventories are now, how should we think about that line item in the second half?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, the line item that we report is gross profit. And interestingly enough, our overall merchandise margins in our Nordstrom brand, our full-price business were roughly equal to last year. Most of the impact we had in negative merchandise margins
componenttext: Sure. Well, the line item that we report is gross profit. And interestingly enough, our overall merchandise margins in our Nordstrom brand, our full-price business were roughly equal to last year. Most of the impact we had in negative merchandise margins came through the off-price business. We also had some deterioration in the gross profit as a result of increased occupancy costs with the opening of new Rack stores. But basically, the regular-priced business was roughly on -- better than -- I'm sorry, better expectations but equal to last year.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Lindsay Drucker Mann from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Lindsay Drucker Mann from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was -- is a big delta versus your expectation in 2Q the stronger execution in Anniversary Sale? And if so, could you talk about maybe some of the things that you might have done differently this Anniversary Sale versus prior sales besides just moving th
componenttext: I was -- is a big delta versus your expectation in 2Q the stronger execution in Anniversary Sale? And if so, could you talk about maybe some of the things that you might have done differently this Anniversary Sale versus prior sales besides just moving the date?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's Pete. No, I think it's fair to say that anniversary was a good catalyst for us in terms of getting some positive top line results, but I think what really made it happen for us is the way that we manage inventories. And we went into a very conse
componenttext: Yes, it's Pete. No, I think it's fair to say that anniversary was a good catalyst for us in terms of getting some positive top line results, but I think what really made it happen for us is the way that we manage inventories. And we went into a very conservative plan at the beginning of the year when we recognized that the sales momentum and trends were tough. We've made adjustments necessary for the sale given the current reality of the sales trends. And so once we got that down, what happened is we ended up having very good sellthrough on our anniversary product, which puts us in a great position for the fall. So that's probably what contributes to the bottom line most is good, just efficient application and deployment of inventory.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Erik. Just mainly as is usually the case, it's a product that drives [indiscernible] anniversary. But I think we did get some lift from the enhancement of our Rewards program. By launching the nontender part of our Rewards program allowed us to co
componenttext: This is Erik. Just mainly as is usually the case, it's a product that drives [indiscernible] anniversary. But I think we did get some lift from the enhancement of our Rewards program. By launching the nontender part of our Rewards program allowed us to connect with customers in a more direct way.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And I was hoping I could just follow up on traffic. Could you comment on sequential changes in traffic?
componenttext: Great. And I was hoping I could just follow up on traffic. Could you comment on sequential changes in traffic?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: We really don track traffic within our stores. I would say generally speaking, it was roughly -- for the quarter, roughly equivalent to what it has been. I don't think there was any big news there.
componenttext: We really don track traffic within our stores. I would say generally speaking, it was roughly -- for the quarter, roughly equivalent to what it has been. I don't think there was any big news there.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Kimberly Greenberger from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Kimberly Greenberger from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, I just wanted to follow up on the merchandise margin comments. I thought you said that the pressure in merchandise margin is coming from the off-price business. Could you just talk about that a little bit? Is that related to return? Is it the off-pr
componenttext: Mike, I just wanted to follow up on the merchandise margin comments. I thought you said that the pressure in merchandise margin is coming from the off-price business. Could you just talk about that a little bit? Is that related to return? Is it the off-price e-commerce business that's pressuring that margin? And did you see any increased markdowns in the full-price business?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Yes, Kimberly, I would say the markdown pressure that we were having in off-price is primarily related to the fact that we're still working through the operational challenges of operating an integrated in-store and online business. We still don't ha
componenttext: Okay. Yes, Kimberly, I would say the markdown pressure that we were having in off-price is primarily related to the fact that we're still working through the operational challenges of operating an integrated in-store and online business. We still don't have all our systems fully Aligned. We're still working through the challenges of taking on line returns in the stores and finding the right way to balance our inventories based on that kind of flow. And so that caused us to take some more markdowns. Now that being said, we continue to make progress there and we're narrowing the gap. And I think as we go forward, that should continue to be a better news story for us. In terms of full-line, the markdowns -- I wouldn't say the markdowns were necessarily better than they were last year, but they were certainly better than our plan for the second quarter.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Omar Saad from Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Omar Saad from Evercore ISI.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to follow up on some of the comments you just made about the loyalty program, the tender agnostic version that you rolled out in May. What you're seeing there? Were you getting a lot of sign-ups from new customers? And how much you are able to ex
componenttext: I wanted to follow up on some of the comments you just made about the loyalty program, the tender agnostic version that you rolled out in May. What you're seeing there? Were you getting a lot of sign-ups from new customers? And how much you are able to expand that program in terms of members? Is the program from the consumer side the same sort of benefits, whether you're participating in the credit card or whether you're tender agnostic loyalty member? What kind of information you can get from that program as you build out that base? It seems pretty interesting from our perspective.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Omar. This is Erik. The program works for a nontender Rewards are 1 point for every dollar spent where it's 2 points for every dollar spent if the customer has our card. So it's a little different level of reward there. The real appeal of [indisce
componenttext: Thanks, Omar. This is Erik. The program works for a nontender Rewards are 1 point for every dollar spent where it's 2 points for every dollar spent if the customer has our card. So it's a little different level of reward there. The real appeal of [indiscernible] to refer one [ph] of our customers, there is just no barrier to sign up. It's an e-mail. The identifier's customer's mobile number, and it takes a few seconds to sign-up and anyone can participate in it. So it's been received really well by customers who just see it is a very friction-free way of enhancing their ending reward for the shopping experience. For us, we've -- as you know, our rewards program has long been one of the main drivers of our business, our retention, our loyalty. And it helps. I mean, given those reward notes that the customer really helps. But the second piece, which I think it's -- which are touching on it is the information, having a lot more customers involved in our program when we've kind of through the quarter about 1.5 million customers into our nontender program. It allows us to, number one, connect with them; and number two, deliver a much more experience for them. So that's the longer-term unlock the we're particularly excited about.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Paul Lejuez from Citi.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Paul Lejuez from Citi.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just getting back to the merchandise margin pressure, Rack. I'm just curious, can you just remind us what percent of Racks' product comes from the full-line stores? And how that changed over the last couple of quarters? Is that having any sort of an impac
componenttext: Just getting back to the merchandise margin pressure, Rack. I'm just curious, can you just remind us what percent of Racks' product comes from the full-line stores? And how that changed over the last couple of quarters? Is that having any sort of an impact on merge margin that Rack is -- when you talk about merge margins, how do you account for the product that transfers from full price to Rack? Is it a count against full price, merge margins or Rack? And just where do you see that mix going forward in terms of what percent of Racks' product comes from full price?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Paul, this is Blake. It's been fairly consistent for some time. And where it does change very slightly is if we change in the material way the amount of Racks we have because the full-line store have been fairly consistent. But it's approximately 15% of t
componenttext: Paul, this is Blake. It's been fairly consistent for some time. And where it does change very slightly is if we change in the material way the amount of Racks we have because the full-line store have been fairly consistent. But it's approximately 15% of the merchandise at this point comes from the full-line stores and then the rest of our merchandise are with our top vendors that closeout and that merchandise allows us to be very current and have good offering and sizes and balance. In terms of the margin and Mike alluded to it earlier, there are different components that affect the markdowns, and part of it is the merchandise that comes from the full-line stores. So we're dealing with immediate impact to date, but there's also a tale to it. So as we're adjusting merchandise over the last first half of the year, it has to go through our system, both the full-line stores and online and then to our Rack. And so some of that stuff didn't sell well at full price has been challenged a little bit at off-price, and so we're taking the necessary markdowns in all of our businesses upfront to try to address what is the right price securities guidance and I think overall the most important thing is weather its the Rack or our stores, we're in one of the best inventory positions we've been in many years. We're able to respond to the customer, partner with our vendors and have good flow, and a lot of good things come from that.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Brian Tunick from RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Brian Tunick from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think last quarter, you talked about a big delta between your sale, customer and your full-price customer. So just wondering, prior to the anniversary sale, if you were seeing any change in customer shopping patterns? And then as far as your gross margi
componenttext: I think last quarter, you talked about a big delta between your sale, customer and your full-price customer. So just wondering, prior to the anniversary sale, if you were seeing any change in customer shopping patterns? And then as far as your gross margin opportunity to recover, price matching I know has been a big issue and now we talk about some of the vendors wanting to pull back themselves from the friends and family and couponing. So just -- have you changed your perspective on what price matching means to your customer now that it seems like every client out there is already looking at transparency?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll take the first one. This is Erik, and Pete can take the second. As far as comparing our regular price customers to our sales customers, the first thing to understand is anniversary is unlike any other sales like we have and I think unlike any other s
componenttext: I'll take the first one. This is Erik, and Pete can take the second. As far as comparing our regular price customers to our sales customers, the first thing to understand is anniversary is unlike any other sales like we have and I think unlike any other sale out there. It's not a clearance sale so it's not older merchandise that's priced the clear out at broken price rents. It's a brand-new merchandise that full-size runs that we mark back up after the sale. So the behavior we've long seen from customers around our anniversary is much more around a regular-priced customer who is motivated by newness than it is the sale customer that's motivated by a price promotion. So in that regard, I would say our trends have, I believe, that have changed that our business continues to be driven by customers were looking for newness as opposed to customers looking for the one-day sale.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: With regards to price matching -- this is Pete, our practice remains the same but I think it's fair to say that the promotional activity has stabilized a bit during the last quarter or so. To the point you've made, there's vendors out there choosing to pa
componenttext: With regards to price matching -- this is Pete, our practice remains the same but I think it's fair to say that the promotional activity has stabilized a bit during the last quarter or so. To the point you've made, there's vendors out there choosing to participate in different price than they may have in the past with our competitors. What we're trying to do is put ourselves in a real favorable position with vendors to be a retailer of choice for them. And what that means for most of the vendors we deal with is our desire, strong desire to sell at full price. So we focus a lot on flow, newness and all that. So I think in terms of the price matching thing, it's -- we've had a lot of success and growth with brands again that are aligned with us and trying to sell at full price and we seek on the growth by brand on some of these brands that maybe our [indiscernible] ubiquitously distributed, but have growth process and try to identify those brands kind of early on in that trajectory so we can arc with them to grow really healthy business together.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Richard Jaffe from Stifel.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Richard Jaffe from Stifel.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: The Canadian business I know has a different leasing structure, and you're ending up paying rent before you generate sales to offset that rent. And wondering where that process stands? I know you've opened a few Canadian stores. Are you now paying rent on
componenttext: The Canadian business I know has a different leasing structure, and you're ending up paying rent before you generate sales to offset that rent. And wondering where that process stands? I know you've opened a few Canadian stores. Are you now paying rent on the next wave of Canadian stores and the size of that liability, if you will? And then a second question if you would.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Richard, this is Mike. As you may recall, we have shared and I think  hared directionally and one of the slides the impact that our investment in Canada is having on our P&L, and some of that does relate to how we need to recognize rent. Right now w
componenttext: Sure. Richard, this is Mike. As you may recall, we have shared and I think  hared directionally and one of the slides the impact that our investment in Canada is having on our P&L, and some of that does relate to how we need to recognize rent. Right now we have 3 full-line stores that are yet to open, that are in process, 2 [ph] that will open this fall that will start to get some sales in the third that will open next spring. So I think some -- in 2017, we should start to see the overall volumes of the 6 stores we'll have there start to move forward and mitigate the loss impact from all those investments.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: I read somewhere that Canada -- I'm sorry, New York City is 2019. Is that in time for the holiday season 2019? Or still a work in progress?
componenttext: I read somewhere that Canada -- I'm sorry, New York City is 2019. Is that in time for the holiday season 2019? Or still a work in progress?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say overall, it's still a work in progress but we'd love to be open by holiday 2019.
componenttext: Well, I would say overall, it's still a work in progress but we'd love to be open by holiday 2019.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's our plan, yes.
componenttext: That's our plan, yes.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ed Yruma from KeyBanc.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ed Yruma from KeyBanc.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just quickly on Trunk Club and looking at the slide you have on 10, it looks you've been able to at this point the minimization of some of the other costs in Canada and Rack.come. How should we think about the cost trajectory at Trunk Club? And then as a
componenttext: Just quickly on Trunk Club and looking at the slide you have on 10, it looks you've been able to at this point the minimization of some of the other costs in Canada and Rack.come. How should we think about the cost trajectory at Trunk Club? And then as a follow-up, I know [indiscernible] tweak your credit income guidance a little bit, so any insight on the drivers there will be helpful.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Erik. I'll take the Trunk Club question. Trunk Club is -- we've had for 2 years, it's still I think very much a startup business that's having high growth are also being line with our expectations, but it's a business that is increasingly being in
componenttext: This is Erik. I'll take the Trunk Club question. Trunk Club is -- we've had for 2 years, it's still I think very much a startup business that's having high growth are also being line with our expectations, but it's a business that is increasingly being integrated in our business. The merchandising and supply chain will be the biggest example. So it certainly helps from a leveraging costs but more it's leveraging capabilities to deliver a better customer experience. So I think you'll see it continue to find ways to integrate and leverage the strengths of our businesses the server customers across this channels.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Add, in terms of the credit size of the businesses, there's a couple of things in there. One is that we've made some very good progress on improving our fraud results, and that has shown a better-than-planned performance. And in addition,, we're starting
componenttext: Add, in terms of the credit size of the businesses, there's a couple of things in there. One is that we've made some very good progress on improving our fraud results, and that has shown a better-than-planned performance. And in addition,, we're starting to see some early signs of some benefits of our partnership from -- in the revenue sharing agreement we have. So we had a loaded news on the top line there and some good news within the expense and credit.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Michael Binetti from UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Michael Binetti from UBS.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you help us on just reconcile a couple things really quickly from a position of strength. I supposed as you've accelerated the article a bit naïve so not much more positive in the outlook there than you have in the last few quarters. But you did lo
componenttext: Could you help us on just reconcile a couple things really quickly from a position of strength. I supposed as you've accelerated the article a bit naïve so not much more positive in the outlook there than you have in the last few quarters. But you did lower your long-term store outlook for Rack. I think it was part of a bigger capital tightening plan. But as the bigger picture relatively -- this is a relatively low store count chain at this point. Can you help us think about how you see the store opportunity longer term here if the reduction that you did make was done more out of a necessity then some fairly high level of productivity in the P&L that the industry saw over the last few quarters?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Michael, this is Blake. We shared a couple of quarters back that we had an estimate that we thought we could be around 300 stores by 2020. We -- our sense is to the capital deployment. But as we've said, the Rack stores have been a good return on the shar
componenttext: Michael, this is Blake. We shared a couple of quarters back that we had an estimate that we thought we could be around 300 stores by 2020. We -- our sense is to the capital deployment. But as we've said, the Rack stores have been a good return on the shareholders investment. I think what we said in our remarks and what we're mindful of is just the terrific growth online that's coming. And we want to be sensitive with our resources in what we are in the short-term committing to. So we didn't have -- when we talked about 300 stores to be exact, that include Canada. We think Canada could have roughly 15 Racks when we're done. We start with our first Rack in 2018, I believe. And so when we put the 15 with kind of the reduced number, we're just shy of 300 at this point, but it's not a linear thing. When these opportunities come forward in key locations, we take advantage of that and that could go up a little bit worried could come down. But to the best of our knowledge today, we think it's just under 300 at this point by 2020.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Tom Forte from Maxim Group.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Tom Forte from Maxim Group.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: So 2 things. On the East Coast fulfillment center, should we think on benefits on shorter ship miles as immediate for something that wraps up over time? And then on mobile e-commerce, can you talk about either conversion or mix of e-commerce sales to curr
componenttext: So 2 things. On the East Coast fulfillment center, should we think on benefits on shorter ship miles as immediate for something that wraps up over time? And then on mobile e-commerce, can you talk about either conversion or mix of e-commerce sales to current from mobile e-commerce? Seems like you've made some adjustments [indiscernible] happen improvements there.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tom, this is Blake. On the East Coast fulfillment center, it's relatively new. We opened it last fall and it's ramping up. The first test was the holiday last year and then our anniversary event. So it hasn't gone to full capacity. So what we're saying is
componenttext: Tom, this is Blake. On the East Coast fulfillment center, it's relatively new. We opened it last fall and it's ramping up. The first test was the holiday last year and then our anniversary event. So it hasn't gone to full capacity. So what we're saying is that we're well positioned where a good portion of our customers live and so we're able to improve the delivery times to our execution. But it's not at full operating strength like our Cedar Rapids facilities been open for sometime. So I think the main thing is were on track at this early point when you're in, and it's providing a meaningful way to service our customers with opportunities to be more efficient down the road.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Erik. On the split between mobile desktop for our e-commerce business. Certainly, mobile is outpacing desktop. It has been for sometime, and we continue to see that. Quite a delta between that -- those channels. And just to clarify, we have 2 ways
componenttext: This is Erik. On the split between mobile desktop for our e-commerce business. Certainly, mobile is outpacing desktop. It has been for sometime, and we continue to see that. Quite a delta between that -- those channels. And just to clarify, we have 2 ways of conducting mobile commerce. One through a mobile browser that is through our app and both we're seeing quite outsized gains.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Neely Tamminga from Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Neely Tamminga from Piper Jaffray.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Erik, for you, I think I remember hearing 5 million sign-ups for the rewards of nontender bases sets. Did I hear that right? And is that still on track? And morbidity anniversary sales are great catalyst to get people to sign up. Are there incremental
componenttext: So Erik, for you, I think I remember hearing 5 million sign-ups for the rewards of nontender bases sets. Did I hear that right? And is that still on track? And morbidity anniversary sales are great catalyst to get people to sign up. Are there incremental events planned in the back half to drive that? And Mike for you, a housekeeping question on SG&A. When you take that big large Anniversary Sale [indiscernible] move it into Q3, I think back in 2012 i,t actually did drive some interesting outside sort of leverage on SG&A. Could you give us a set of contextualization the guidance around how we should be thinking about the SG&A leverage in Q3 this year because of the shift?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Neely, yes, we look at it as 1 program. It's our fashion works program, and there's 2 ways for customers to participate. Roughly 6 million participants in the program and including the early stages of the nontender offer there. Anniversary provides tremen
componenttext: Neely, yes, we look at it as 1 program. It's our fashion works program, and there's 2 ways for customers to participate. Roughly 6 million participants in the program and including the early stages of the nontender offer there. Anniversary provides tremendous opportunity to sign up customers for our Rewards program. To have always as it's been a big driver of opening our credit accounts previously. Now it does provide opportunity to additionally add the nontender portion of it. So we're very pleased with the rates of sign-ups in both the card and the nontender, and we have a lot of plans to continue that.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Neely, in terms of the SG&A, we haven't broken that out by quarter. Those assumptions are included in our guidance for the year. But that being said, it's probably a relatively consistent directionally accurate relationship between what happened in 2012.
componenttext: Neely, in terms of the SG&A, we haven't broken that out by quarter. Those assumptions are included in our guidance for the year. But that being said, it's probably a relatively consistent directionally accurate relationship between what happened in 2012.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Oliver Chen from Cowen.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Oliver Chen from Cowen.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was curious about your customer research. On your customer research, what would you say customers really want that you don't yet offer? And what are the longer-term implications for how you allocate CapEx towards IT to kind of address what's evolving th
componenttext: I was curious about your customer research. On your customer research, what would you say customers really want that you don't yet offer? Also related to the future just on a long-term basis, how do you see your brand composition evolving in terms of ensuring that you have the specialness that is required in this new version of retail that we're in now?
