And maybe what you're seeing the other -- the only vendor outside of those?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Greg. This is Mike. I'll take the first part of the SG&A. In terms of the progress we're making, we feel really good about how we've been able to bend the curve and the growth in a number of areas. Whether or not that 5% is going to maintain past 20
componenttext: Sure, Greg. This is Mike. I'll take the first part of the SG&A. In terms of the progress we're making, we feel really good about how we've been able to bend the curve and the growth in a number of areas. Whether or not that 5% is going to maintain past 2016, we'll let you know about that in February when we talk about our 2017 plans. But suffice it to say, we feel like there's opportunity for us to continue to improve upon that. And certainly, the 1 challenge we do have there is the fastest-growing piece of our business is the e-commerce piece and that has the most variable element. So we have to keep all those things in mind that there's many dynamics happening here that prevent us from just fixing in a lot number. But that being said, we think in terms of stabilizing operating margins, we've been able to make some good progress.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Pete. Related to the fastest growing vendors, yes, we have some bright spots but I think you can just ascertain from the fact that our business is fairly flat in comps. That means we have some bigger brands that are probably decelerating, too. So
componenttext: This is Pete. Related to the fastest growing vendors, yes, we have some bright spots but I think you can just ascertain from the fact that our business is fairly flat in comps. That means we have some bigger brands that are probably decelerating, too. So it all works it self out. I think for us, though, it's nice to have some positive parts and bits to point to, and these brands thought across a lot of different categories. So I think it gives us a lot of purpose about going forward, how we plan our business, the people that we are working with, where we feel like we've got a momentum and future with and making sure [indiscernible] the brands or maybe going the other way that we're planning them accordingly, too, so we don't get ourselves into inventory bench. A big part of what you've seen in terms of our improved results have to do purely of the fact that our sales are growing faster than inventory, and the benefit of all that is what you're seeing here in our results.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016

componenttext: This is Cody on for Adrian today. The beauty category has been growing for a while across the industry. One of your competitors recently cited a slowdown in this category. What are you seeing? And if you're seeing a slowdown, do you this is more of our product of the industry slowing down? Or somewhere someone else taking market share?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our beauty business has been strong relative to be other categories for seems like a couple of years now, and it continues to be that way. So Beauty as a classification performed above the average of all of our product categories. So we continue to see go
componenttext: Our beauty business has been strong relative to be other categories for seems like a couple of years now, and it continues to be that way. So Beauty as a classification performed above the average of all of our product categories. So we continue to see good progress there. We got a good team that works really hard to bring newness and some limited distribution vendors to our assortments and that's been a good formula.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016

componenttext: Next is Paul Trussell with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016

componenttext: When it comes to the multichannel comp, fairly in line with kind of maybe expectations we had, but the mix was quite different. What's very surprised is given the anniversary shift to still see the full-line comp down 4.5. Were there specific initiatives that you all had in the third quarter to drive maybe more traffic towards the dotcom? Or if you could just speak on the brick-and-mortar full-line versus the dotcom?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Paul, this is Jamie, I'll take that one. Yes, I think what you're seeing is the continuing trend that we've been seeing for a while around mall traffic. I don't think it's any secret out there that there's been some declines. And depending on a lot of the
componenttext: Paul, this is Jamie, I'll take that one. Yes, I think what you're seeing is the continuing trend that we've been seeing for a while around mall traffic. I don't think it's any secret out there that there's been some declines. And depending on a lot of the reports that you look at, mall traffic is down anywhere 4% to 5% based on the budget and reports and what we see, and that's pretty consistent with how our trends have been. And so what are we doing about that? Well, we are investing a lot in our e-commerce experience, and you see the results there. We're pretty happy with the growth we're starting to see there, and there's been -- it's paying off some investments we've been making over the last couple of years. Within the store, there's also some encouraging signs and results around some new experiences  that we're trying to drag using technology, using mobile to not only make the customers experience in the stores more convenient, more compelling, but also drive more trips. So some things we've been piloting over the last 6 months we feel good about, and we're looking forward to continue to drive some reasons for customers to come visit our stores and maybe bock some of these trends going forward.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016

componenttext: Next is Mark Altschwager with Robert W. Baird.

componenttext: Maybe elaborating on that last comment. I guess, could you just talk a little bit more about some of the initiatives around your digital shopping experience? I think you talked about efforts to edit the assortment and maybe leverage salesperson product knowledge. Just curious how all that's evolving? And what are the opportunities you see to further differentiate your online experience versus both pure play, play online and omni-channel competitors?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, I'll take that, and Erik, if you want to jump in. A lot of what we're trying to do in the stores is give customers control, and mobile is such a great medium for that. So recently, we launched in our [indiscernible] stores as a pilot a feature calle
componenttext: Sure, I'll take that, and Erik, if you want to jump in. A lot of what we're trying to do in the stores is give customers control, and mobile is such a great medium for that. So recently, we launched in our [indiscernible] stores as a pilot a feature called reserve online trend in-store and it allows customers to take merchandise out on their phone through our mobile app and they can have that merchandise placed in a dressing room. We know when the customer shows up, we have already informed. They can walk and try it on what they want to buy. We can check it on real fast. And the results from that over the last month or so have been really, really encouraging and really looking forward to rolling that on nationally in 2017. So a lot of deployment of technology that we've been investing in and building over the last couple of years into the customers' hands to make shopping our stores way more convenient and compelling. We think that's going to drive some trips. E, do you want to take the second part of that?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I would reemphasize, as we brought up the last several quarters just a context of -- we really run the business agnostic to those channels, and that's because that's how our customers shop. So while we do, accounting was a break things out, full-lin
componenttext: Sure. I would reemphasize, as we brought up the last several quarters just a context of -- we really run the business agnostic to those channels, and that's because that's how our customers shop. So while we do, accounting was a break things out, full-line stores and e-commerce, there's so much overlap between those businesses and that is increasing. And Jamie gave one example there. The store reserve, which is we're excited about because it's a very explicit seamless experience that connects shopping journey that starts online and ends up in a store. We know that have lots of our customers have been shopping, but they have to start -- they start online and when they go in the store, they want to actually see it, touch it, feel it, try it on and start over. This allows them not to start over. So a lot of our initiatives are around continuing to take out friction between the channels and really deliver experience that is consistent with how customers want to shop. But that being said, online the last quarter, some of our initiatives that got put into place. We have a redesigned homeplace experience that's performing well. We have a store mode in search and browse that is both on our full website and in our app, and that's again would be an example of really connecting online and off-line shopping experience. We've improved our navigation, had some personalization, small stuff that we're excited about. And our redesign of our order confirmation, order history. A lot of these are some subtle changes that don't pop up the page, but have -- had positive results as we then maybe testing on them. On the app, in addition to the store mode, we launched visual search. We also integrated -- we had a separate catalog app we've integrated into our main NordstromRack.com app, and we also launched search and messaging within I message. And all these are looking to make the shopping experience more friction free and on the customer terms.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Brian Tunic with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Brian Tunic with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is [indiscernible] on for Brian. I just want to ask about gross margins longer term. Beyond the opportunity to recover maybe some of the gross margin declines in Q4, what are some of the buckets within your postal foothold or the investments that hav
componenttext: This is [indiscernible] on for Brian. I just want to ask about gross margins longer term. Beyond the opportunity to recover maybe some of the gross margin declines in Q4, what are some of the buckets within your postal foothold or the investments that have been hurting your gross margins over the last few years that you maybe the most opportunities to improve, to help you get gross margins maybe closer to 36%, 37% range over the next 2 [ph] years?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. This is Mike. There are several components that have been affecting that line, and the ones that have had the most significant impact are really related to the evolving mix of our business in a way our business is changing. So a couple of examples t
componenttext: Sure. This is Mike. There are several components that have been affecting that line, and the ones that have had the most significant impact are really related to the evolving mix of our business in a way our business is changing. So a couple of examples there are at the Rack business, the off-price business continues to grow faster than the other businesses. That has a lower gross margin element. It also has a lot of expense element so the operating margin tends to be pretty comparable, but it does affect that gross profit line. In addition, the growth of our loyalty business has put in some pressure on that over time. I think in terms of what have been the more shorter-term impacts and some of the good news we've seen recently that's been a function of the sales trends we've seen, the excess inventory last year. And as we start to come out of that and have better controls over our inventories based on the current environment we're in, we're seeing positive in the margin. But I think it's fair to say it's tough to see getting that line back to historical highs, because there are structural elements to it, both at the business level as well as the assortment level where we're seeing some changes in mix.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Bob Drbul with Guggenheim.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Bob Drbul with Guggenheim.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of quick questions. In the Trunk Club, can you detail a little more on the operational changes you are making to make it more profitable? And can you comment a little bit around the footwear category? How your positioned? The selling season,
componenttext: Just a couple of quick questions. In the Trunk Club, can you detail a little more on the operational changes you are making to make it more profitable? And can you comment a little bit around the footwear category? How your positioned? The selling season, winter boots and fashion boots?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Bob. E can you comment on Trunk Club, please.
componenttext: Sure, Bob. E can you comment on Trunk Club, please.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I'm actually in Chicago with something to do with our Trunk Club team here. Yes, I would want to emphasize, while we're taking the write-down as needed, we're actually very encouraged with what we've learned, the teams learned and how to make the mo
componenttext: Sure. I'm actually in Chicago with something to do with our Trunk Club team here. Yes, I would want to emphasize, while we're taking the write-down as needed, we're actually very encouraged with what we've learned, the teams learned and how to make the model that are. In the model, we're focused on is really making it better for customers. When we make the model better for our customers, the economic model improves as well. And 2 areas that, I guess, I would call out without getting too specific. One, we think we have an opportunity and we've seen better results and better connecting with our customers in a more consistent basis that gets them sticky with the brand. And the other that we could be more accurate in what we put in the trunks, what we're sending out to customers. That makes so much better customer experience and it helps the model significantly.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Pete. Related to the question about shoes and boots, in particular, seasonal. We got an early view of that with anniversary sale. And so the fashion oriented part of the boot classification, short booties, the over-the-knee boots is -- was all str
componenttext: This is Pete. Related to the question about shoes and boots, in particular, seasonal. We got an early view of that with anniversary sale. And so the fashion oriented part of the boot classification, short booties, the over-the-knee boots is -- was all strong and really good. So I think as the weather starts kicking in across the country, we expect that, that will be a good classification for us. Still kind of early days on that, but seems like we have a pretty good handle on what's happening with that trend. I'd also say that the sneaker business continue to be strong kind of across all the different genders of shoes and what we're selling.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ed Yruma with KeyBanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ed Yruma with KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the credit card business and loyalty, I know that you intended to fund some of the nontender rewards through kind of efficiencies in advertising. So I guess, have you begun to implement that. And I guess, second, have there been any implications or cha
componenttext: On the credit card business and loyalty, I know that you intended to fund some of the nontender rewards through kind of efficiencies in advertising. So I guess, have you begun to implement that. And I guess, second, have there been any implications or changes in sign-up pattern to the traditional credit card now that you can get the rewards with the nontender system?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Ed. Well, this is Mike. In terms of efficiency with marketing, I think it's a little early for that. As you know, we just introduced it in May. We've had a very nice response. We've built a good book of business around that with people signing up. B
componenttext: Sure, Ed. Well, this is Mike. In terms of efficiency with marketing, I think it's a little early for that. As you know, we just introduced it in May. We've had a very nice response. We've built a good book of business around that with people signing up. But I think that's going to take a little bit of time in order for us to see, I would say, tangible impact of our ability to be more efficient with our marketing. With that being said, we're up to 45% of our business connecting with those customers so that's very, very positive as we look forward. In terms of -- could you please remind me the second part of the question?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Just asking if there's been any changes in credit card sign-ups? Or how the implication nontender may impact that decision?
componenttext: Yes. Just asking if there's been any changes in credit card sign-ups? Or how the implication nontender may impact that decision?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Ed, we have seen a slowdown in the sign them up -- sign-ups of the tender-related side of the business. In the aggregate for both sides, we have -- we've seen very, very promising results, but certainly, on the tender side, it has slowed down a littl
componenttext: Yes. Ed, we have seen a slowdown in the sign them up -- sign-ups of the tender-related side of the business. In the aggregate for both sides, we have -- we've seen very, very promising results, but certainly, on the tender side, it has slowed down a little bit.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Richard Jaffe with Stifel.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: The main floor business, if you could just comment and I'll be -- fragrances, beauty, handbags, accessories. I know you called out Women's Apparel as strong, and I assume that's not the main floor. Could you go into some of these other categories and how
componenttext: The main floor business, if you could just comment and I'll be -- fragrances, beauty, handbags, accessories. I know you called out Women's Apparel as strong, and I assume that's not the main floor. Could you go into some of these other categories and how they're doing vis-à-vis the Women's Apparel business?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Pete. The Women's Apparel business has been pretty good for us and where we got the best successes what we would clarify some of customer stops them largely have to do with our top shelf business, but really anything that's kind of about acqu
componenttext: Yes. This is Pete. The Women's Apparel business has been pretty good for us and where we got the best successes what we would clarify some of customer stops them largely have to do with our top shelf business, but really anything that's kind of about acquiring a new customer and speaking to a particular millennial customer. That's been particularly good in Women's Apparel. In terms of the main floor part of it, Beauty has been strong, shoes been relatively strong. The challenge has been really kind of in the accessory categories, particularly jewelry, accessories and a chunk of a high end bag is it more for us be the entry or middle type prices. Our designer business across shoes and base apparel has been good. That continues to outperform. So it's a large portfolio of categories to look at there, but we definitely have some parts of the business that have gone well. I mean, you heard us call out the J.Crew and the Great American brand, and there's a lot of initiatives and things that we're trying, particularly when it's apparel that maybe speaks to the younger customer that's helping us with sales and helping us acquire new customers and again giving us something really to focus on going forward. That's going to hopefully bear some good results for us.

componenttext: You raised your credit outlook -- your outlook for credit income, and I was wondering it sounds like it wasn't because of the increase in sign up. What is really driving the underlying profitability there? Is it higher balances? I guess, just tell us the reason for the increase.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Oliver Chen with Cowen & Company.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Oliver Chen with Cowen & Company.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Regarding the churn for inventory ahead, inventories have been really sharp. So just for the next few quarters, should we expect a continued conservative stance on inventories in versus sales? And another question we had is on shipping costs. Shipping cos
componenttext: Regarding the churn for inventory ahead, inventories have been really sharp. So just for the next few quarters, should we expect a continued conservative stance on inventories in versus sales? And another question we had is on shipping costs. Shipping costs as a percentage of sales. What do you think will happen to that line item as the business and as consumers and kind of the DC and the nonlinearization of supply chain kind of occurs? Just curious on your thoughts.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well I'm going to let Blake or Mike deal with that shipping one. But in terms of inventory levels, yes, it's fundamental to our bottom line performance to manage inventories well. You go through those cycles and learn painful lessons along the way. We did
componenttext: Well I'm going to let Blake or Mike deal with that shipping one. But in terms of inventory levels, yes, it's fundamental to our bottom line performance to manage inventories well. You go through those cycles and learn painful lessons along the way. We did a pretty good job correcting, first of all, our sales plans have been more reflective of what the reality of the trends are and then getting inventories down. We did that beginning of the year and we were benefiting from that now. So our plans going forward reflect the last year or so trends, which Mike talked about earlier have been pretty consistent. So I guess, some of you that is kind of conservative, I think that serves as well. If this doesn't improve, it's usually [indiscernible] position that's pretty easy to find pretty in inventory out there, things are improving. So we feel like we're in pretty good shape and well served to keep our conservative [indiscernible] in our planning so the inventory stays in line.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Albert, this is Blake. I'll touch on the shipping projects. Supply chain has become a integral part of our customer service. As we said over and over, our focus is on customers. So the last couple of years, we've made some pretty big investments to ensure
componenttext: Albert, this is Blake. I'll touch on the shipping projects. Supply chain has become a integral part of our customer service. As we said over and over, our focus is on customers. So the last couple of years, we've made some pretty big investments to ensure that our supply chain is [indiscernible] with our customers' demands. I think the biggest thing as you mentioned some of the fees or costs. Mike pulled out in his remarks, I believe, roughly $15 million in savings throughout this year that we're finding back to [indiscernible] as some opportunities for the big picture mix subject you mentioned this revision centers versus performance centers. We continue to see year in, year end core efficiencies in the distribution part of it, which is more of a apples to apples. The mix of timing and the type of goods of how we're getting goods to customers and then there's the return, reverse logistics subject in aggregate means more costs. And so working really hard on that to, number one, first of all, meet the customers' demand; and number two, meet our goals and results and our shareholders that we're doing it in an efficient manner.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: And lastly, we took a walk at Toronto, which had a lot of principles which really don't seem easily replicated by Amazon and a unique elevated approach to service. What are some of the learnings from your store to the future that will -- you'll prioritize
componenttext: And lastly, we took a walk at Toronto, which had a lot of principles which really don't seem easily replicated by Amazon and a unique elevated approach to service. What are some of the learnings from your store to the future that will -- you'll prioritize in terms of getting out to your other stores as soon as possible just because that store in Toronto had a lot of unique excitement around service and experiences, which seemed quite lively and helpful for store traffic.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Oliver, this is Jamie. Thanks for that. I'm glad we get to that store. We just opened 2 stores in Toronto over the last couple of months, and we always say whenever we open up a store, that it's our best store ever. And those stores particularly, we're ve
componenttext: Oliver, this is Jamie. Thanks for that. I'm glad we get to that store. We just opened 2 stores in Toronto over the last couple of months, and we always say whenever we open up a store, that it's our best store ever. And those stores particularly, we're very proud of and we're going for it. We've got a good team up there. Our store managers are -- of those 2 stores are 2 of our best and in terms of service we're really going for it. You mentioned some special things that we've been doing there, along with some of our other what we would call a bigger market kind of flagship stores and is momentarily audience in Chicago, Vancouver, downtown Seattle where it's not just have about having a broader offering of the line is, which we do but having more specialized services to serve customers in lots of different ways, and that could mean anything from delivery merchandise to their house, picking them up, bringing to the store. We've got food and beverage offering in those stores that are pretty unique and so far customers are going to spray feedback on and ultimately, we want the stores to be really comp could places, they really compelling places that people want to go and see something you. And a better job we do in all of our stores, but particularly our [indiscernible] traffic stores assuming that the some of that something is new giving them a reason to buy something new the better our businesses. So we're really, really encouraged my some of the early results from those stores and things that we can replicate across our entire fleet. And I think you'll see us doing that over the next year or 2.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Michael Binetti with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Michael Binetti with UBS.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can we just get an idea -- a lot of my questions were answered. Can I -- or 2 in here. Can we just give an idea of the profile maybe of menu towards customer compared to the narrower credit card reward customer from before changes in frequency you notice
componenttext: Can we just get an idea -- a lot of my questions were answered. Can I -- or 2 in here. Can we just give an idea of the profile maybe of menu towards customer compared to the narrower credit card reward customer from before changes in frequency you notice or maybe more importantly, how does the gross margin on the sale of a nontender loyalty compared to the previous generation rewards customer?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Michael, I would say just in general, the nontender customer tends to be -- it's a broader appeal product. The tender product qualifications for having that card, we have very, very high FICA standards that tended to be somebody that it had a longer histo
componenttext: Michael, I would say just in general, the nontender customer tends to be -- it's a broader appeal product. The tender product qualifications for having that card, we have very, very high FICA standards that tended to be somebody that it had a longer history of spending that could justify getting that card. The nontender, we don't have that, so we're attracting a much broader customer, it's allowing us to engage with our younger customer that is coming through their cycle with us and introduce them to some of our benefits and to the conveniences of shopping with Nordstrom. In terms of the economics, I would say just by its very nature, you're going to have higher spend with a credit card oriented product versus a non-credit card oriented product. In terms of margin, I don't think I haven't any numbers in front of me that tells me the impact to that. But I think the most important thing, it's like we talked about opening the Rack stores. We're attracting a lot of new customers through our brand and those customers will continue to grow with us.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I could just sneak one more in. I know you're not going to talk about the plan for beyond this year, but can we talk about just some of the high level items impacting the cost line today and we should be thinking about longer term as we go into next ye
componenttext: If I could just sneak one more in. I know you're not going to talk about the plan for beyond this year, but can we talk about just some of the high level items impacting the cost line today and we should be thinking about longer term as we go into next year and maybe some of those that will not be a factor. Looking out past this year, we see the cost saving you guys have rolling through in the report today. But I think you lapped some dead rent in Canada next year. You have less Trunk Club amortization now lin gross margin line, some of the price matching continue to next year. Can you just help us think about some of the puts and takes on a bigger bucket as we into next year for a model?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Michael, it sounds like you figured it out. I would just reinforce the fact that the 3 main areas that we continue to focus on, technology, supply chain and marketing, they continue to be critical because those are the areas of investment that are driving
componenttext: Michael, it sounds like you figured it out. I would just reinforce the fact that the 3 main areas that we continue to focus on, technology, supply chain and marketing, they continue to be critical because those are the areas of investment that are driving the new platform for growth, and that's e-commerce and anything digital related. So we're going to have to continue to figure out how to use of those resources more effectively and find ways to deliver the experience more efficiently, because they're very, very -- highly variable in nature. And the more that, that business grows, the more those costs are going to go up. So I think that's going to be a multiyear effort on our part. I think the other things we talked about, you're right, tend to be a little bit more shorter term. The investments we've made, yes, we are starting to see the impact to the earnings line start to narrow. We saw some improvement in 2016. We should see additional improvement next year and the years to come.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016

componenttext: That's absolutely correct, and so there's a timing difference there. We saw a slight improvement in NordstromRack.com, and what you're looking at, Lindsay, is the Nordstrom and HauteLook was down at this trend if we make that adjustment for what happen in our supply chain side, it's pretty consistent with our trends.

componenttext: Greetings, and welcome to the Nordstrom Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. At this time, I'll turn the call over to Trina Schurman, Director of Investor Relations for Nordstrom. You may begin.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. Today's earnings call will last 45 minutes and will include 30 minutes for your questions.Before we begin, I want to mention that our speakers will be referring to slides which can be viewed by going to nord
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. Today's earnings call will last 45 minutes and will include 30 minutes for your questions.
Before we begin, I want to mention that our speakers will be referring to slides which can be viewed by going to nordstrom.com in the Investor Relations section. Today's discussion may include forward-looking statements, so please refer to the slide showing our safe harbor language.
Participating in today's call are Blake Nordstrom, Co-President; and Mike Koppel, Chief Financial Officer, who will discuss the company's third quarter performance and the outlook for fiscal year 2016. Joining during the Q&A session will be Pete and Erik Nordstrom, Co-Presidents; and Jamie Nordstrom, President of Stores.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Blake.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, everyone. Our third quarter results reflected our team's substantial progress in making both adjustments to align the current business trends and longer-term changes to our business model. Before we get started, I'd like to first address
componenttext:
Good afternoon, everyone. Our third quarter results reflected our team's substantial progress in making both adjustments to align the current business trends and longer-term changes to our business model. 
Before we get started, I'd like to first address the write-down related to Trunk Club. In August 2014, we acquired this start-up as a new channel to serve customers in a personalized and relevant way. Unfortunately, the business has not performed to the expectations we had when we acquired it, and as a result, we have reduced the value of that asset. Trunk Club continues to be well aligned with our customer service commitment and value proposition. We remain committed to this business and view it as a part of our customer strategy. Mike will later discuss the adjustments we are making to assure its future success.
Now I'd like to move on to our third quarter performance. From a top line perspective, our third quarter benefited from 1 week of our Anniversary Sale shifting into the quarter. This shift contributed to a comp increase of 2.4% over last year. To get a better sense of underlying trends, the combined second and third quarter comps were up 0.4%. This is consistent with the trends we've been seeing over the past year.
As the pace of customer expectations continues to accelerate, it's even more important for us to remain focused on the customer. We are in the midst of evolving our business model to better support shifts in how our customers are shopping with us. While this is a continuous journey, we've made considerable changes in the way we operate to improve the customer experience and increase our productivity. We're extremely proud of our team's efforts over the past year to align inventories and gain greater efficiencies. These outcomes have positively impacted our third quarter results and adds to our confidence as we continue to make improvements to our operating model. Our strategy is squarely focused on serving customers on their terms with a high level of product and service they expect from us.
This quarter, we have executed on a number of initiatives to better serve customers and drive top line growth. In our Nordstrom brand, we achieved another milestone related to our Canada expansion with 2 successful store openings in Toronto at Eaton Centre and Yorkdale Center. With Toronto being the fourth-largest market in North America, we believe these stores will be among our top volume stores. They are in outstanding locations, and we're excited about their potential. We now have 5 stores open in Canada and look forward to opening our sixth, also in greater Toronto area at Sherway Gardens next fall. In the U.S., we have successful opening of our second store in Austin, Texas, at the Domain. 
Our Rack business serves as a great way of attracting new customers to Nordstrom. We expanded our reach with 15 new stores this fall for a total of 215 Racks. These stores are complemented by our nordstromrack.com and HauteLook businesses, which are expected to reach over 700 million sales this year. Offering a curated product assortment is an integral element of our customer strategy. 
In the third quarter, we launched new collaborations with J.Crew and denim brand Good American. Also in collaboration with Nike, we rolled out a women's lifestyle concept shop at our downtown Seattle and Eaton Centre stores, followed by our Michigan Avenue store later this month. Through these partnerships, we were able to give our customers compelling product that has limited distribution.
We have an unwavering focus on serving customers. This approach guides us on how we set our priorities, allocate resources and accelerate the speed of our execution. As we head into the holiday season, we are planning the business consistent with the sales trends we've been seeing over the past year. 
On the inventory and expense side, we have strong momentum in place and remain committed to continuing our progress to ensure we're best positioned to manage our business.
Now I'd like to turn it over to Mike.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Blake. Our third quarter results demonstrated the progress we are making to improve our operating model. Over the last year, we've been addressing not only the challenges of top line trends but the longer-term impacts of operating a fast-growing e
componenttext:
Thanks, Blake. Our third quarter results demonstrated the progress we are making to improve our operating model. Over the last year, we've been addressing not only the challenges of top line trends but the longer-term impacts of operating a fast-growing e-commerce business. In this quarter's performance, we realized the operating leverage generated by these adjustments, in particular, from inventory and expense. We will continue to identify opportunities to improve our longer-term performance as our business continues to evolve.
Before providing more color on the quarter, I'd like to also address our plans related to Trunk Club. As Blake mentioned, because of our revised performance expectations, we recognized a noncash impairment in the Trunk Club goodwill of $197 million. While we've reset our performance goals, we continue to believe that Trunk Club provides us with unique customer experience that we can build upon. To that end, we are making a number of improvements to better serve customers. The initial results have been favorable for our customers and improved our economics.
To help get Trunk Club customers a broader selection of brands, we are also integrating supply chain and fulfillment capabilities over the next year. We anticipate that these and other changes we're making will drive continued growth and improve Trunk Club's results going forward.
Moving to our third quarter performance. Our top line trends were generally consistent with what we've experienced over the past year. We've continued our progress in growing relevant brands that have limited distribution.
In our full price business, our top 20 fastest growing vendors, which includes many of the brands with limited distribution and our private label business, collectively grew 20% in the third quarter. In response to the changes in consumer demand, we aggressively aligned our inventory plans and made significant progress in stabilizing our operating margins over the past 2 quarters combined. We ended the third quarter with a positive spread between sales and inventory growth. Inventories are well positioned and current as we head into the important holiday season.
Stepping back, we've made strategic investments over the past 5 years to meet changing customer expectations. This enabled us to grow our top line by 50%. As we move forward, we will continue to adapt our operating model to provide an exemplary customer experience and deliver long-term profitable growth.
This year, we've made tremendous progress in rightsizing our expense trajectory through increased efficiencies across our enterprise capabilities. This includes our efforts to expand our digital experience, which is enabled through technology. For example, we've upgraded a vast majority of our website platform, which allows us to accelerate the continuous delivery of new customer-facing features.
From a productivity standpoint, we've prioritized our investments toward modernizing our infrastructure and implementing the highest-value customer experiences.
In supply chain, we have implemented a number of initiatives focused on improving the customer experience and reducing per-unit costs. Based on these efforts, we are on track to achieve savings of roughly $50 million in shipping and fulfillment costs this year. 
In marketing, our expanded Nordstrom awards loyalty program represents a meaningful opportunity to directly engage with customers, drive customer lifetime value and increase the efficiency of our marketing spend. Since the launch of our nontender offer in mid-May, we now have more than 7 million customers in our overall program, up over 40% from a year ago. In the third quarter, the spend from our loyalty customers made up 45% of our sales, which increased around 600 basis points from last year.
Finally, I'd like to provide additional color on our financial outlook for the year. Excluding impairment charge, we've raised our full year earnings per share outlook to $2.85 to $2.95 from our prior outlook of $2.60 to $2.75 to incorporate third quarter results. From a top line perspective, we anticipate a continuation of trends yielding flat comps for the year.
In closing, we will continue to aggressively prioritize our resources to ensure that we provide a relevant best-in-class experience for our customers while achieving profitable growth. Through our ongoing efforts, we are confident that Nordstrom will remain relevant to customers now and in the future.
I'll now turn it over to Trina for Q&A.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike. [Operator Instructions] We will now move to the Q&A session.
componenttext: Thanks, Mike. [Operator Instructions] We will now move to the Q&A session.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Matthew Boss with JPMorgan.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: So gross margin performance this quarter, the best in over 5 years. Mike, if you broke down the 100 basis points here in the third quarter, what was the underlying merchandise margin trend? Any impact from the Trunk Club change? And just the best way to t
componenttext: So gross margin performance this quarter, the best in over 5 years. Mike, if you broke down the 100 basis points here in the third quarter, what was the underlying merchandise margin trend? Any impact from the Trunk Club change? And just the best way to think about ongoing opportunity into the fourth quarter and beyond.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Sure, Matt. Well, thanks for your question. Of the improvement in the gross profit line, roughly 1/3 of it was direct from merchandise margin performance. The balance was leverage we're getting on sales and the buy-in and occupancy cost. The story is
componenttext: Yes. Sure, Matt. Well, thanks for your question. Of the improvement in the gross profit line, roughly 1/3 of it was direct from merchandise margin performance. The balance was leverage we're getting on sales and the buy-in and occupancy cost. The story is pretty consistent with what we started to see as we've aligned inventories, not only our inventories, but inventories around the industry. There's less promotion out there. We have less excess inventory, so we're seeing more stability in margins. I think in terms of how we feel going forward, we've reflected that in our outlook and, certainly, the -- any variance from the outlook would be determined by how we perform on the top line.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Lorraine Hutchinson with Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Lorraine Hutchinson with Bank of America.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to follow up on SG&A. I was wondering which initiatives drove the 70 basis point positive variance in the quarter. And also would you expect similar leverage in the fourth quarter?
componenttext: I wanted to follow up on SG&A. I was wondering which initiatives drove the 70 basis point positive variance in the quarter. And also would you expect similar leverage in the fourth quarter?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Lorraine. This is Mike. We didn't really break out the elements of that 70 basis points. I will tell you, collectively, we've seen some great progress amongst those 3 main areas that we called out as well as just generally operating our business in t
componenttext: Yes, Lorraine. This is Mike. We didn't really break out the elements of that 70 basis points. I will tell you, collectively, we've seen some great progress amongst those 3 main areas that we called out as well as just generally operating our business in the core everyday element of it. In terms of what we see going forward, again, I will give a similar answer as I did with gross profit. We've reflected our expectations in the outlook, and any ability for us to gain additional leverage will clearly be driven by sales.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jeff Stein with NorthCoast Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jeff Stein with NorthCoast Research.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, so if we look at the fourth quarter outlook, basically at the high end, you're looking for relatively flat and, at the low end, down about $0.10. And with the improvement that you saw in gross margin and SG&A in the third quarter, what's changing be
componenttext: Mike, so if we look at the fourth quarter outlook, basically at the high end, you're looking for relatively flat and, at the low end, down about $0.10. And with the improvement that you saw in gross margin and SG&A in the third quarter, what's changing between Q3 and Q4 that would cause you to be, at best, flat based on your revised guidance?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jeff, that's a great question. I think there's a couple of elements to consider. One is the fact that part of the leverage, while we did get 70 points of leverage from normal activity, we're still looking at a sales environment that, while some folks may
componenttext: Jeff, that's a great question. I think there's a couple of elements to consider. One is the fact that part of the leverage, while we did get 70 points of leverage from normal activity, we're still looking at a sales environment that, while some folks may feel a little better about, the trends have been pretty consistent for the last couple quarters, and we're managing our business accordingly. So it's purely driven by the expectations at the top line. We expect to continue to achieve some good expense performance. But again, in terms of the margin impact of it, it's going to be sales driven.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. But it would seem to me, if you're looking for flat comps for the year, that would imply a more [ph] comp trend in Q4 that you saw in Q3, correct?
componenttext: Okay. But it would seem to me, if you're looking for flat comps for the year, that would imply a more [ph] comp trend in Q4 that you saw in Q3, correct?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's correct.
componenttext: That's correct.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Neely Tamminga with Piper Jaffray.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016

componenttext: Congrats, Mike, on your pending retirement.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Much, much deserved. Big shoes to fill, guys. Big shoes. So here's what we really want to know on the Rack side of the business. Rack is kind of suddenly just been performing pretty well here in this environment. And what we want to get a sense of is just
componenttext: Much, much deserved. Big shoes to fill, guys. Big shoes. So here's what we really want to know on the Rack side of the business. Rack is kind of suddenly just been performing pretty well here in this environment. And what we want to get a sense of is just what does the content look like as you kind of head into Q4? How are you feeling about things? How are you feeling about the Rack trends? And I guess, more specifically, how have the categories within Rack been performing? I think you had some commentary in the release around the full line, but what are the category performances going on at Rack?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Neely, this is Blake. We're really pleased with our team's effort that have been focused on a number of initiatives for a couple of years now, and it's a pretty simple playbook in terms of what resonates with the customer, but the opportunity is to make s
componenttext: Neely, this is Blake. We're really pleased with our team's effort that have been focused on a number of initiatives for a couple of years now, and it's a pretty simple playbook in terms of what resonates with the customer, but the opportunity is to make sure that we're executing well on behalf of the customer. There's a whole range of things we're focused on from improving the experience at point of sales to the dressing room and ensuring that the stores are filled in, in size. And so I think the numbers are just reflective of the team's efforts and the customers' great response to that. And inherent in all that is do we have the right merchandise, and is -- a good value. Is there integrity in our pricing. So you mentioned the last part of your question is kind of what's selling, and what's the content of our inventory? Well, just like the full-line stores, the inventory levels in off-price Nordstrom Rack are as current as we've seen in a long time. And we're fluid. We have open to buy and the flow's improving and the customer's responding to that. So we've gone from maybe a year ago or [ph] 6 months ago where we didn't have that open to buy and we have margin pressure, and there's just a good ripple effect or Halo from that. So we're encouraged by that, and I think we're heading in the right direction there.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Kimberly Greenberger with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Kimberly Greenberger with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Greg Baglione on for Kimberly. I have 2 quick questions. One is from the slide deck. It says looks like here, you have total SG&A dollars, [indiscernible] 5% for 2016. Is that like a run rate that we should model going forward? Do you think it's s
componenttext: This is Greg Baglione on for Kimberly. I have 2 quick questions. One is from the slide deck. It says looks like here, you have total SG&A dollars, [indiscernible] 5% for 2016. Is that like a run rate that we should model going forward? Do you think it's sustainable? And then I think earlier, you mentioned that your top 20 fastest-growing vendors increased 20% during the quarter. Can you just list now what percentage of the business they comprise and maybe what you're seeing the other vendors outside of those?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Greg. This is Mike. I'll take the first part of the SG&A. In terms of the progress we're making, we feel really good about how we've been able to bend the curve and the growth in a number of areas. Whether or not that 5% is going to maintain past 20
componenttext: Sure, Greg. This is Mike. I'll take the first part of the SG&A. In terms of the progress we're making, we feel really good about how we've been able to bend the curve and the growth in a number of areas. Whether or not that 5% is going to maintain past 2016, we'll let you know about that in February when we talk about our 2017 plans. But suffice it to say, we feel like there's opportunity for us to continue to improve upon that. And certainly, the one challenge we do have there is the fastest-growing piece of our business is the e-commerce piece and that has the most variable element. So we have to keep all those things in mind that there's many dynamics happening here that prevent us from just fixing in on a locked number. But that being said, we think in terms of stabilizing operating margins, we've been able to make some good progress.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Pete. Related to the fastest-growing vendors, yes, we have some bright spots, but I think you could just ascertain from the fact that our business is fairly flat in comps, that means we have some bigger brands that are probably decelerating, too.
componenttext: This is Pete. Related to the fastest-growing vendors, yes, we have some bright spots, but I think you could just ascertain from the fact that our business is fairly flat in comps, that means we have some bigger brands that are probably decelerating, too. So it all works itself out. I think for us, though, it's nice to have some positive parts of the business to point to, and these brands cut across a lot of different categories. So I think it gives us a lot of purpose about going forward, how we plan our business, the people that we are working with, where we feel like we've got a momentum and future with and making sure conversely on the brands that are maybe going the other way that we're planning them accordingly, too, so we don't get ourselves an inventory pinch. A big part of what you've seen in terms of our improved results have to do purely of the fact that our sales are growing faster at inventory, and the benefit of all that is what you're seeing here in our results.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Adrienne Yih with Wolfe Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Adrienne Yih with Wolfe Research.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is, actually, Cody on for Adrienne today. Quick question, so the beauty category has been growing for a while across the industry. One of your competitors recently cited a slowdown in this category. What are you seeing? And if you are seeing a slowdo
componenttext: This is, actually, Cody on for Adrienne today. Quick question, so the beauty category has been growing for a while across the industry. One of your competitors recently cited a slowdown in this category. What are you seeing? And if you are seeing a slowdown, do you this is more of our product of the industry slowing down or someone else taking market share?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our beauty business has been strong relative to the other categories for seems like a couple years now and it continues to be that way. So beauty as a classification performed above the average of all of our product categories. So we continue to see good
componenttext: Our beauty business has been strong relative to the other categories for seems like a couple years now and it continues to be that way. So beauty as a classification performed above the average of all of our product categories. So we continue to see good progress there. We got a good team that works really hard to bring newness and some limited distribution vendors to our assortments, and that's been a good formula.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next is Paul Trussell with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Next is Paul Trussell with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: When it comes to the multichannel comp, fairly in line with kind of maybe expectations we had, but the mix was quite different. What's very surprised is given the anniversary shift to still see the full-line comp down 4.5. Were there specific initiatives
componenttext: When it comes to the multichannel comp, fairly in line with kind of maybe expectations we had, but the mix was quite different. What's very surprised is given the anniversary shift to still see the full-line comp down 4.5. Were there specific initiatives that you all had in the third quarter to drive maybe more traffic towards the dotcom? Or if you can just speak on the brick-and-mortar full-line versus the dotcom?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Paul, this is Jamie. I'll take that one. Yes, I think what you're seeing is the continuing trend that we've been seeing for a while around mall traffic. I don't think it's any secret out there that there's been some declines. And depending on a lot of the
componenttext: Paul, this is Jamie. I'll take that one. Yes, I think what you're seeing is the continuing trend that we've been seeing for a while around mall traffic. I don't think it's any secret out there that there's been some declines. And depending on a lot of the reports that you look at, mall traffic is down anywhere 4% to 5% based on a bunch of different reports that what we see, and that's pretty consistent with how our trends have been. And so what are we doing about that? Well, we are investing a lot in our e-commerce experience, and you see the results there. We're pretty happy with the growth we're starting to see there, and there's been -- it's the paying off of some investments we've been making over the last couple years. Within the store, there's also some encouraging signs of some -- and results around some new experiences that we're trying to drag using technology, using mobile to not only make the customers' experience in the store more convenient, more compelling but also drive more trips. So some things that we've been piloting over the last 6 months we feel good about, and we're looking forward to continue to drive some reasons for customers to come visit our stores and maybe buck some of these trends going forward.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next is Mark Altschwager with Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Next is Mark Altschwager with Robert W. Baird.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe elaborating on that last comment, I guess, could you just talk a little bit more about some of the initiatives around your digital shopping experience? I think you talked about efforts to edit the assortment and maybe leverage salesperson product kn
componenttext: Maybe elaborating on that last comment, I guess, could you just talk a little bit more about some of the initiatives around your digital shopping experience? I think you talked about efforts to edit the assortment and maybe leverage salesperson product knowledge. Just curious how all that's evolving? And what other opportunities you see to further differentiate your online experience versus both pure play online and omnichannel competitors?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, I'll take that, and Erik, if you want to jump in. A lot of what we're trying to do in the stores is give customers control, and mobile is such a great medium for that. So recently, we launched in our Seattle area stores as a pilot a feature called r
componenttext: Sure, I'll take that, and Erik, if you want to jump in. A lot of what we're trying to do in the stores is give customers control, and mobile is such a great medium for that. So recently, we launched in our Seattle area stores as a pilot a feature called reserve online tryout in store, and it allows customers to pick merchandise out on their phone through our mobile app, and they can have that merchandise placed in a dressing room. We know when the customer shows up. We have it ready for them. They can walk in, try on what they want to buy. We can check them out real fast. And the results from that over the last month or so have been really, really encouraging and really looking forward to rolling that out nationally in 2017. So a lot of deployment of technology that we've been investing in and building over the last couple years into the customers' hands to make shopping our stores way more convenient and compelling. We think that's going to drive some trips. E, if you want to take the second part of that?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I would reemphasize, as we brought up the last several quarters just the context of -- we really run the business agnostic to those channels, and that's because it's how our customers shop. So while we do accounting-wise break things out, full-line
componenttext: Sure. I would reemphasize, as we brought up the last several quarters just the context of -- we really run the business agnostic to those channels, and that's because it's how our customers shop. So while we do accounting-wise break things out, full-line stores and e-commerce, there's so much overlap between those businesses, and that is increasing. And Jamie gave one example there, the store reserve, which is we're excited about because it's a very explicit seamless experience that connects a shopping journey that starts online and ends up in a store. We know that's how lots of our customers have been shopping, but they have to start -- they start online, and when they go in the store, they want to actually see it, touch it, feel it, try it on. They have to start over. This allows them not to start over. So a lot of our initiatives are around continuing to take out friction between the channels and really deliver experience that is consistent with how customers want to shop. But that being said, online in the last quarter, some of our initiatives that got put into place, we have a redesigned homepage experience that is performing well. We have a store mode in search and browse that is both on our full website and in our app, and that's, again, would be an example of really connecting online and off-line shopping experience. We've improved our navigation, had some personalization, small stuff that we're excited about and our redesign of our order confirmation, order history. A lot of these are some subtle changes that don't pop up the page but have -- had positive results as we've done AB testing on them. On the app, in addition to the store mode, we launched visual search. We also integrated -- we had a separate catalog app we've integrated into our main Nordstrom app. We also launched search and messaging within I iMessage. And all these are looking to make the shopping experience more friction free and on the customer terms.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Brian Tunic with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Brian Tunic with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Deela Moyer [ph] on for Brian. I guess he wanted to ask about gross margins longer term. Beyond the opportunity to recover maybe some of the gross margin declines in Q4, what are some of the buckets within your postal foothold or the investments t
componenttext: This is Deela Moyer [ph] on for Brian. I guess he wanted to ask about gross margins longer term. Beyond the opportunity to recover maybe some of the gross margin declines in Q4, what are some of the buckets within your postal foothold or the investments that have been hurting your gross margins over the last few years that you maybe see most opportunities to improve, to help you get gross margins maybe closer to 36%, 37% range over the next few years?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. This is Mike. There's several components that have been affecting that line, and the ones that have had the most significant impact are really related to the evolving mix of our business in the way our business is changing. So a couple of examples t
componenttext: Sure. This is Mike. There's several components that have been affecting that line, and the ones that have had the most significant impact are really related to the evolving mix of our business in the way our business is changing. So a couple of examples there are at the Rack business, the off-price business continues to grow faster than the other businesses. That has a lower gross margin element. It also has a lower expense element, so the operating margin tends to be pretty comparable, but it does affect that gross profit line. In addition, the growth of our loyalty business has put in some pressure on that over time. I think in terms of what have been the more shorter-term impacts and some of the good news we've seen recently, that's been a function of the sales trends we've seen, the excess inventory last year. And as we start to come out of that and have better controls over our inventories based on the current environment we're in, we're seeing positive in the margin. But I think it's fair to say it's tough to see getting that line back to historical highs because there's structural elements to it, both at the business level as well as the assortment level where we're seeing some changes in mix.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Bob Drbul with Guggenheim.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Bob Drbul with Guggenheim.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of quick questions. In the Trunk Club, can you detail a little more on the operational changes you are making to make it more profitable? And can you comment a little bit around the footwear category? How your positioned? The selling season,
componenttext: Just a couple of quick questions. In the Trunk Club, can you detail a little more on the operational changes you are making to make it more profitable? And can you comment a little bit around the footwear category? How your positioned? The selling season, winter boots and fashion boots?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Bob. E, can you comment on Trunk Club, please.
componenttext: Sure, Bob. E, can you comment on Trunk Club, please.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I'm actually in Chicago with something to do with our Trunk Club team here. Yes, I would want to emphasize, while we're taking the write-down as needed, we're actually very encouraged with what we've learned, the teams learned and how to make the mo
componenttext: Sure. I'm actually in Chicago with something to do with our Trunk Club team here. Yes, I would want to emphasize, while we're taking the write-down as needed, we're actually very encouraged with what we've learned, the teams learned and how to make the model better. And the model we're focused on is really making it better for customers. When we make the model better for our customers, the economic model improves as well. And 2 areas that, I guess, I would call out without getting too specific, one, we think we have an opportunity and we've seen some early results and just better connecting with our customers in a more consistent basis that gets them sticky with the brand. And the other that we could be more accurate in what we put in the trunks, what we're sending out to customers. That makes for a much better customer experience, and it helps the model significantly.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Pete. Related to the question about shoes and boots, in particular, seasonal. We got an early view of that with Anniversary Sale. And so the fashion-oriented part of the boot classification, short booties to over-the-knee boots is -- was all stron
componenttext: This is Pete. Related to the question about shoes and boots, in particular, seasonal. We got an early view of that with Anniversary Sale. And so the fashion-oriented part of the boot classification, short booties to over-the-knee boots is -- was all strong and really good. So I think as the weather starts kicking in across the country, we expect that, that'll be a good classification for us. Still kind of early days on that, but seems like we have a pretty good handle on what's happening with that trend. I'd also say that the sneaker business continued to be strong kind of across all the different genders of shoes and what we're selling.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016

componenttext: On the credit card business and loyalty, I know that you intended to fund some of the nontender rewards through kind of efficiencies in advertising. So I guess, have you begun to implement that. And I guess, second, have there been any implications or changes in sign-up pattern to the traditional credit card now that you can get the rewards with the nontender system?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Ed. Well, this is Mike. In terms of efficiencies in marketing, I think it's a little early for that. As you know, we just introduced it in May. We've had a very nice response. We've built a good book of business around that with people signing up. B
componenttext: Sure, Ed. Well, this is Mike. In terms of efficiencies in marketing, I think it's a little early for that. As you know, we just introduced it in May. We've had a very nice response. We've built a good book of business around that with people signing up. But I think that's going to take a little bit of time in order for us to see, I would say, tangible impact of our ability to be more efficient with our marketing. With that being said, we're up to 45% of our business connecting with those customers, so that's very, very positive as we look forward. In terms of -- could you please remind me your second part of the question?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Just asking if there'd been any changes in credit card sign-ups? Or how the implication nontender may impact that business?
componenttext: Yes. Just asking if there'd been any changes in credit card sign-ups? Or how the implication nontender may impact that business?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016

componenttext: Yes. Ed, we have seen a slowdown in the sign-ups of the tender-related side of the business. In the aggregate for both sides, we've seen very, very promising results but, certainly, on the tender side, it has slowed down a little bit.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, my congratulations to you and wish the best in the next part of your career. The main floor business, if you could just comment and that'd be fragrances, beauty, handbags, accessories. I know you called out Women's Apparel as strong, and I assume th
componenttext: Mike, my congratulations to you and wish the best in the next part of your career. The main floor business, if you could just comment and that'd be fragrances, beauty, handbags, accessories. I know you called out Women's Apparel as strong, and I assume that's not the main floor. Could you go into some of these other categories and how they're doing vis-à-vis the Women's Apparel business?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Pete. The Women's Apparel business has been pretty good for us in that where we got the best success is what we would classify as kind of the young customer stuff that largely has to do with our top shop business but really anything that's ki
componenttext: Yes. This is Pete. The Women's Apparel business has been pretty good for us in that where we got the best success is what we would classify as kind of the young customer stuff that largely has to do with our top shop business but really anything that's kind of about acquiring a new customer and speaking directly to a millennial customer, that's been particularly good in Women's Apparel. In terms of the main floor part of it, Beauty has been strong, shoes have been relatively strong. The challenge has been really kind of in the accessory categories, particularly jewelry, accessories and a chunk of handbag business, kind of that more kind of for us be the entry or middle type prices. Our designer business across shoes and base apparel has been good. That continues to outperform. So it's a large portfolio of categories to look at there, but we definitely have some parts of the business that have gone well. I mean, you heard us call out the J.Crew and the Good American brand, and there's a lot of initiatives and things that we're trying, particularly in Women's Apparel that maybe speaks to a bit [ph] of the younger customer that's helping us with sales and helping us acquire new customers and again giving us something really to focus on going forward that's going to hopefully bear some good results for us.
